A pilot fell from the ladder while boarding the tanker, south of the Bosphorus. Another crew member jumped into the water and retrieved him but he was unconscious. He was rushed to the hospital where he passed away due to hypothermia.
Container ship had engine problem due to a fault with injector leaking, 3.87nm from S.Fools Bouy, UK. She anchored for repairs, which took aproximately six hours.
Vessel ran aground whileheading to berth in St. Petersburg port of Bronka, Russia. Transport Prosecutor's Office organised an inspection. No injuries or pollution reported.
Container ship was boarded by two perpetrators at Chittagong anchorage, Bangladesh. The alarm was raised and the two individuals fled empty handed. Bangladesh Coast Guard was informed of incident.
Nine stowaways were found in the rudder compartment at Apapa-Lagos anchorage by a patrol team. They were handed over to the the Nigerian Immigration Service.
Vessel ran aground off the port of Gedser, Denmark. She was refloated and detained for damage examination. No injuries reported. She arrived back in Rostock, the same day.

Ferry Kevalay Queen and cargo ship Captain Adam 1 collided at the southern entrance of the Istanbul Strait at Sarayburnu Point, while en route from Haydarpasa to Misurat. Both vessels sustained damages above waterline and were towed to Akhyrkapi pier, awaiting damage surveys and inspections. No reports of injuries or pollution.

Vessel suffered technical failure at N entrance of Canakkale Strait at Gelibolu point, Turkey. Strait transit passage was temporarily cancelled and shifted to Sevketiye anchorage under own power. Repairs were carried out by crew.

Cargo ship Captain Adam 1 collided with ferry Kevalay Queen at the southern entrance of the Istanbul Strait at Sarayburnu Point, while en route from Alexandria, Egypt to Sulina. Both vessels sustained damages above waterline and were towed to Akhyrkapi pier, awaiting damage surveys and inspections. No reports of injuries or pollution.
A fire broke out in gas cylinder while docked at asphalt plant in Bingsa Industrial Area in Alesund,Norway. Fire was extinguished and a drone was deployed to assess temperature onboard.
Cargo vessel had technical failure of navigation system and pertinent alarm units at Yesilyurt in Samsun, Turkey. Sailing was banned until repairs were completed.

Fishing vessel encountered engine problems  while off NW coast of Spain. CCS Fisterra mobilised Spanish rescue vessel Salvamar Altair and towed her to port of Muxia, Spain, where they arrived the same day.
Vessel was NUC due to propulsion loss although the engine was still running 4.65 NM from Dungeness point, UK. Repairs were completed the same day.
Houthi Rebels claim to have targeted the “American Merchant Ship” KOI with appropriate naval missiles. The vessel was reportedly heading to a Palestinian port. The claim has not been verified yet.

The semi-submersible rig had equipment failure 200 km west of the Shetland Islands, on contract with BP. The malfunction involved the rig’s lower marine riser package (LMRP), which separated from the rig at the slip joint tensioner ring and fell to the seabed. Because of harsh weather the LMRP had been disconnected from the rig’s blowout preventer (BOP) on the well. There were no injuries and no reports of damages to the seabed infrastructure.

Cargo vessel allided with new Northern lock of Kiel Canal in Kiel-Holtenau, while en route from Antwerp, Belgium to Rostock, Germany. Vessel anchored at Kiel anchorage for investigations and resumed voyage the next day.

Vessel suffered a fault in the power supply to the main engine, 25nm south of Lizard Point, UK, while en route from Sydney, Nova Scotia, Canada to Rostock, Germany. Issue was rectified and vessel continued voyage.

High speed ferry collided with water taxi HOP & GO 1 near Matoco Point in Batangas City, while en route from Batangas to Calapan, Philippines. The water taxi was severely damaged and the captain and third mate died. Other four passengers suffered serious injuries. Coast Guard responded and transferred all passengers to Calapan. Safety certificates for both vessels have been suspended and an investigation in underway.
Vessel had a technical failure at Gemlik, Turkey. Departure permission was cancelled until completion of repairs. Repairs are carried out at Gemlik.
Container ship ran into embankment of Kiel Canal near Schwartenbek, Germany during transit. She was pulled out again by a tug and berthed at railway station pilings in Brunsbuttel.
Tanker experienced technical failure during Canakkale Strait passage, Turkey. She anchored at Karanlik liman anchorage for repairs.
Fishing vessel was NUC due to engine failure, in English Channel. Fishing vessel Glorieviergemarie will be towing her to Boulogne. No other assistance required.
Reports container ship was NUC and drifting in North Sea waters, Netherlands. Vessels in the area were requested to give the vessel a wide berth.

Tanker allided with pier during berthing at Haydarpasa, Turkey.  There were structural damages to fore part, forecastle deck manoeuvring station and pertinent connections. She was shifted to Tuzla shipyard and resumed sailing on 25 February.

Vessel experienced engine failure with loss of power at Yenikoy point, Turkey. Tug Kurtarma-10 and fast rescue boat Liman Kontrol-9 were dispatched to secure the vessel. She dropped anchor at Yenikapi anchoarge for repairs.
Ferry suffered main engine failure in Strait of Georgia, BC, Canada. She resumed voyage using remaining engine to Nanaimo, before proceeding to Horseshoe Bay, for repairs.
Vessel suffered propulsion failure while serving between East Cowes and Southampton, UK. Sailings from Southampton and East Cowes were cancelled.
Vessel detained by port state control in Gibraltar after its Russian crew complained they had not been paid. "situation blamed on the Western sanctions regime targeting Russia."
A minor crack in the hull was found while at anchorage No. 6 off Prince Rupert, Canada. Vessel remained anchored until repairs and inspection were completed.
Tug suffered damages to one of the propellers after striking an unknown object under water, while assisting a cargo vessel for berthing in Quebec, Canada. OCEAN K. RUSBY proceeded to its wharf.
Cargo ship collided with several boats at Nafplion port, Greece, as she was carried away by stormy winds prevailing in the area. Vessel was stationary at Nafplion as of 31 January.

Ferry collided with quay in Trelleborg, Sweden while manoeuvring in port. She suffered damages to bow bulb which caused water ingress into bow tank. Vessel berthed in Szczecin for repairs and sailed on 18 February.
Bulk carrier had an engine failure upon departure from Becancour, Quebec, Canada. The crew carried out repairs and resumed voyage the same day.

Crew members spotted a small, makeshift boat with 12 refugees urgently seeking assistance, while sailing through the Gulf of Mexico. Vessel turned around to rescue them. They had been at sea for 6 weeks, with water and food supplies critically low. They received medical attention and food and were taken to Costa Maya, Mexico, the cruise ship’s next port of call.
Cargo ship suffered engine failure south of Bozcaada Island, Turkey. Tug Turkeli towed the vessel and tug Kurtarma 3 provided escort service to Tuzla.
Vessel experienced a technical failure at Ambarli, Turkey and shifted from the port to anchorage. Repairs were carried out by the crew.

Cargo ship sank 10nm north of Con Dao Island, while en route from An Giang, Vietnam to Indonesia. All crew members are safe. Vung Tau, Vietnam Maritime Port Authority warned vessels in the vicinity about the wreck.
A technical problem was detected while docked in Marseille, France. Technical analysis and necessary repairs were carried out and vessel sailed on 8 February.
Cargo vesselwas NUC due to turbocharger issues in English Channel, UK. She moved to St Helens anchorage, Isle of Wight and sailed after repairs on 31 January, bound for Las Palmas.

Vessel experienced engine issues and anchored roughly 20km offshore and outside the Pacific Rim National Park Reserve’s jurisdiction, en route from Vancouver, Canada, to Osaka, Japan. ATLANTIC EAGLE was dispatched to assist, but as of 8 February the vessel was off the Aleutian Islands, Alaska, USA and appeared to have resumed voyage to Osaka.
Vessel lost control of pipeline it was installing off Pilbara coast, Australia, forcing an evacuation of workers and damaging pipeline. Woodside halted installation.

Cargo ship collided with southern embankment during Kiel Canal transit, in Schacht-Audorf, Germany. She proceeded to communal port of Rendsburg for investigations and after a hull survey, she was able to resume voyage the same day.

Vessel allided with northern head of breakwater during berthing manoeuvring at Haydarpasa, Turkey, on arrival from Novorossiysk, Russia. She shifted to Yenikapi anchorage under the supervision of tug Mehmetcik.
Ferry was sidelined at Southampton, UK until further notice due to an oil leak on the port jet unit.

Two men on a kayak were spotted by crew members while off the coast of Isla Mujeres, Mexico. They said that their sailboat started sinking and had to use the kayak. After the rescue they were transferred to the Mexican Navy through Carnival’s Fleet Operation Center in Miami.

Tanker suffered propulsion failure and was towed through Baltic Sea off Fehmarn by several tugs, but got stuck in ice off St. Petersburg, Russia for several days before entering the port. Her rudder was damaged.
Vessel allided with pier at Donkey Beach, Bonaire, Caribbean Netherlands, due to portside engine fault. She suffered a crack in hull in ballast tank area with no leaks reported.
Tanker allided with berth and suffered a hole in the bow and port side , in Milford Haven, UK. No tug assistance was required and no pollution reported.

Australian police found 139 kg of cocaine, worth $29.00m, hidden within 13 luxury buses on board the vessel, at Freemantle. The vessel sails between Singapore and Adelaide, with a stop at Freemantle. Two men were arrested in connection to the drug seizure and appeared in court. They are facing a maximum sentence of life imprisonment.

Bulk carrier allided with southwestern pylon of a bridge connecting Buenos Aires with Argentina's northern Entre Rios province. Parana River Waterway was closed. An investigation is underway, although reports say the cause of the incident could be rudder failure. Vessel suffered extensive damage on the port side with a significant hole both above and below the waterline.
Cargo ship suffered technical failure of the structural system and pertinent certificates at Poti, Georgia. Departure permission temporarily was cancelled until repair works are carried out.
Product tanker Bahari Maju II collided with the vessel at Pertamina Plaju Jetty, S Sumatra, Indonesia. She suffered dents and minor scratches on starboard side of hull.

Vessel experienced technical issues during transit of Kiel Canal and berthed at railway station pilings in Brunsbuttel, Germany. Two tugs pulled to bunker station on 29 January. Sailing ban was lifted on 30 January.
A small electrical fire broke out in one of the engine room storerooms. The fire was extinguished promptly without any damages reported.
Bulk carrier suffered main engine failure upon departure from an anchorage in Indian Arm, Canada. She reanchored for repairs and once effected she resumed voyage.

Cargo ship suffered engine failure in Bosphorus Strait, Turkey while en route to Kalymnos, Greece. The vessel halted mid-transit and blocked traffic in both directions. Istanbul Ship Traffic Services Center coordinated the rescue with the help of Rescue Tug-7 and tugboat MEHMETCIK. SNP PAZAR was anchored at Ahirkapi Anchorage and strait traffic returned to normal.
Vessel collided with product tanker Palu Sipat/Pertamina 1025 at Pertamina Plaju Jetty in South Sumatra, Indonesia. She allegedly lost control after having engine failure. Investigation underway.

Oil tanker Marlin Luanda caught fire in Red Sea after missile attack by Yemen's Houthi fighters. A Houthi spokesman said the attack was in support "of the oppressed Palestinian people" and in response "to the American-British aggression against our country". The fire has since been extinguished and everyone on the crew is reported to be safe. https://news.sky.com/story/oil-tanker-on-fire-in-red-sea-after-missile-attack-by-houthi-fighters-13057225

The bulk carrier allided with the wharf in Port of Kitakyushu, Japan and suffered a 2.5 metre long and 45cm wide gash in the right rudder bow and a crack of up to 85 centimetres in the quay buffer. Repairs were carried our and vessel sailed from Kitakyushu on 31 January.

Passenger ship suffered water ingress in bow in Bulla area of Caspian Sea, 30km from coast of Azerbaija. Nearby passenger vessels Gobustan and Maiden Tower rescued the people on board, while supply vessel Caspian Spirit towed vessel to Baku.
Hull of vessel collided with the stern of ferry Adithya, while attempting to dock at the Nusantara Parepare Port in Indonesia. There were no reports of injuries. An investigation was launched.

Hull of vessel MADANI NUSANTARA collided with the stern of fADITHYA, while attempting to dock at the Nusantara Parepare Port in Indonesia. There were no reports of injuries. An investigation was launched.
Cargo ship had technical failure during Canakkale Strait passage and dropped anchor at Karanlik liman anchorage for repairs by crew.

While en route from Cozumel, Mexico to Galveston, Texas, the cruise ship sailed through three bouts of rain, hail and high winds. There was some water ingress in state rooms and balconies and some minor injuries to a few passengers caused by moving slot machines in the casino. The crew handled the situation professionally.

MSC MARYLENA II had technical failure, at northern entrance of Canakkale strait at Gelibolu point, Turkey. Sailing was banned and vessel shifted to Sevketiye anchorage under own power. Repairs were carried out by the crew.
Container ship veered off course and allided with a buoy which was securing construction site of new lock in Brunsbuttel, Germany. Vessel was inspected after berthing inside lock.

A fire broke out on board the vessel, while moored in Kaliningrad, Russia. Firefighters evacuated the crew and completely extinguished fire. Cause of the fire was determined to be depressurisation and subsequent fire of gas cylinder in storage room.

Security concerns are heightened in the Arabian Sea, as Iran converted boxship SARVIN into a drone carrier at the ISOICO shipyard near Bandar Abbas and is now controlled by the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. The drone carrier is named SHAHID BAGHERI and is expected to cause disruptions to vessels in the Arabian Sea.

Tanker has been freed by Albania after 10 months of detention on allegations that she was carrying Russian oil. She was seized in February 2023 by Albanian officials at the port of Porto Romanoto, although the vessel's operator maintained his claim that the oil came from Azerbaijan and was loaded through ship-to-ship transfer in Greece. As of 24 January, the ship was moored at Tuzla, Turkey.
Vessel was NUC after an engine sensor error & black out in North Sea waters, UK. Repairs were done and resumed voyage.

Tanker had engine failure in Aliaga, Turkey. Tug Yumurtalik provided assistance and coastal Safety tug Kurtarma-14 escorted her to Tuzla shipyard. Vessel arrived in shipyard area of Altinova on 14 February.
Tug suffered main engine failure upon departure from Port of Montreal, Canada. Vessel proceeded to section 57 and the crew assessed the issue.

Vessel ran aground after the generator and the emergency generator stopped working. A Japan Air Self-Defence Force helicopter transferred all crew to Toyama Airport. She drifted for 200m and developed a port side list before running aground.
Cargo ship had issues with propulsion, auxiliary engines and pertinent alarm systems at Tuapse, Russia. Departure permission was temporarily cancelled until repairs are done.
Vessel suffered mechanical failure at Gemlik, Turkey. Sailing was banned until repairs are done.
Vessel had mechnical failure at Samsun, Turkey and shifted to anchorage for repairs. Departure permission was temporarily cancelled by Harbour-Master.
Ferry had technical issue with navigation lights serving on Oban-Lismore, UK route. An electrician attended to investigate and carry repairs. Vessel resumed sailing the next day.
Cargo ship suffered mechanical failure at Diliskelesi, Turkey and shifted to Gebze anchorage for repairs. Departure permission was cancelled until repairs are done.
Vessel had high temperature of exhaust gases in cylinder of starboard main engine and cooling water temperature increased. Sailing was banned at Igoumenitsa. No injury or pollution reported.

Cargo ship had rudder failure during eastbound transit of Kiel Canal and ran into the embankment of waterway at Claustal near Breiholz, Germany. Tug Fairplay 64 towed her to port of Rendsburg for repairs.
Ferry had serious malfunction in steering and manoeuvring system at Tarrafal de Sao Nicolau pier, Cape Verde. She was towed to island of Sao Vicente for repairs.

Container ships MAERSK DETROIT and MAERSK CHESAPEAKE reported they detected  explosions in the vicinity when passing through the Bab el-Mandeb with a US Navy Escort. They reversed course and headed away from the strait and will be diverted through the Cape of Good Hope. The US Central Command declared that the Iranian backed Houthi militants fired three anti-ship ballistic missiles, targeting the vessels. One of them impacted in the sea, while the other two were shot down by the USS Gravely (DDG 107). Maersk announced that they will suspend operations in the Red Sea for their US flagged vessels.

Container ships MAERSK DETROIT and MAERSK CHESAPEAKE reported they detected  explosions in the vicinity when passing through the Bab el-Mandeb with a US Navy Escort. They reversed course and headed away from the strait and will be diverted through the Cape of Good Hope. The US Central Command declared that the Iranian backed Houthi militants fired three anti-ship ballistic missiles, targeting the vessels. One of them impacted in the sea, while the other two were shot down by the USS Gravely (DDG 107). Maersk announced that they will suspend operations in the Red Sea for their US flagged vessels.
Vehicles carrier was NUC and needed to replace main engine exhaust valve, 26 NM S of East Prawle, UK, while en route from Emden, Germany to Halifax, Canada. She continued voyage after repairs.
Bulk carrier was NUC due to engine alarm issue, in English Channel. Repairs were sone but later she had engine cylinder overheat again. She continued voyage on 25 January after repairs.
Bulk carrier had issues with an auxiliary engine, emergency systems and alarm units at Zonguldak, Turkey. Repairs were carried out by the crew and sailed from Zonguldak on 26 January.

Ferry suffered damages to the starboard hull during undocking, at shipyard Oresund Drydocks AB, Landskrona, Sweden where she had been docked since 9 January for maintenance. Repairs to the hull are required and sailing is set to resume on 30 January.
Cargo ship collided with general cargo with container capacity Astrid L at Istanbul anchorage, Turkeyon. She suffered damages at portside bulwark of bow and shifted to Kartal anchorage for repairs.

Bulk carriers MIRABELLA and OMEGA were involved in a collision around 15 nautical miles off the Yangtze River Estuary. There were no reports of injuries. Both vessels sustained serious damages. MIRABELLA was partly flooded but managed to anchor in safe waters. She was en route from Tuticorin, India, to Taicang, China.
Ferry had technical issues while serving the route between Trondheim and Kristiansund, Norway. Sailed from Trondheim same day.

Bulk carriers MIRABELLA and OMEGA were involved in a collision around 15 nautical miles off the Yangtze River Estuary. There were no reports of injuries. Both vessels sustained serious damages. OMEGA started taking on water due to a breach in number 5 cargo hold and was in danger of sinking. All crew on board were evacuated.
General cargo Volgo-Don 207 collided with the vessel at Istanbul anchorage, Turkey. She suffered damage to bulbous bow but there were no injuries or pollution. She shifted to Yalova for repairs.

A Houthi spokesperson declared that the rebels hit the vessel, but did not give any details about location or damages. The US Navy denied the claims and stated that NAVCENT has been in contact with the vessel throughout her journey to the Red Sea.
Ferry had issues with the propeller and had to return to Sandefjord. She resumes service the following day after repairs and tests were carried out,

A crew member was in need of immediate medical attention, about 210nm off the Isles of Scilly. UK MRCC requested nearby vessels with medical facilities to attend, however, the man died one hour later. The vessel arrived at A Coruna, north-west Spain on 23 January.
Vessel's portside anchor got entangled with the starboard anchor of ferry AKRITAS at Lavrio, Greece. This caused the AKRITAS to collide with cruise ship CELESTYAL DISCOVERY.

Ferry had engine breakdown with smoke development on her way to Brattvag, Norway. 2 people suffered smoke inhalation and were treated by ambulance boat. A naval vessel towed ferry to port and was then sent to shipyard for inspection.
AKRITAS collided with cruise ship CELESTYAL DISCOVERY at Lavrio, Greece, after her starboard anchor got entangled with portside anchor of cruise ship AEGEAN ODYSSEY. AKRITAS sailed the next day.

Vessel suffered starboard main engine fault while serving between Ardrossan and Brodick, UK. Essential maintenance works were being carried out during recent weather cancellations. Spare parts were delivered and vessel sailed on 24 January.
Tanker suffered mechanical damage in Kafirea Strait, Greece. She continued voyage next day, after repairs at anchorage of Karystos Bay.

Starboard side of ferry Akritas collided with starboard side side of CELESTYAL DISCOVERY which led to her anchor being entangled to with the anchor of passenger vessel AEGEAN ODYSSEY, at Lavrio, Greece.
Ferry's sailing on Ceuta - Algeciras line were cancelled due to a breakdown after leaving port of Algeciras, Spain. She was towed to Algeciras port and then towed to Ceuta for repairs.
Bulk carrier suffered failure of fuel supply system in St. Lawrence River, 2.30nm of Pointe aux Sables, QC, Canada. Vessel was moored at Sainte-Victoire-de-Sorel.
Ferry was sidelined in Tadoussac due to a failure in the main engine communication system, while operating on route Tadoussac-Baie-Sainte-Catherine Traverse, Canada. Crew carried out repairs.

Bulk carrier suffered a fault in the main engine fuel supply system in English Bay, 2.20nm SE of Point Atkinson, BC, Canada. She dropped anchor and crew assessed issue. Vessel sailed from Vancouver anchorage on 25 January.

Passenger ship had engine failure while sailing between Espevaer and Eidesvik on Bomlo, Norway, during storm. NSSR Naval Vessel Rs Hans Herman Horn was dispatched from Haugesund to assist and towed her to Eidesvik.

Passenger ship was hit by high waves and allided with pier. She suffered damages and could not depart on her scheduled trip from Paciran Lamongan Harbor to Bawean Island. As of 29 January vessel was "stopped" to the south-east of bandar Lumpung.
A crack was detected during routine inspections on radar pillar. This required the ferry to  come out of service andmove to Oban for repairs. She resumed sailings next day.
Ferry experienced engine failure and departure from from Sandnessjoen to Traena, Norway was delayed until later in the day.
Sailings on the route Stavanger - Byoyene - Hommersak, Norway were cancelled due to technical issues. Vessel remained sidelined in Stavanger for repairs.
Water tanker suffered engine failure with loss of power and dropped anchor, off Erdek, Turkey. Coast Guard emergency helicopter team attended and evacuated all crew. Tug Esenkiyi also attended.
Smoke was detected on board the vessel docked at Sassnitz, Germany. The cause was a defective heat exchanger, open fire was ruled out.

Four stowaways were discovered in one of the vessel's food stores, one hour after departure from La Goulette, Tunisia bound for Genoa, Italy. The ship returned to La Goulette to hand over the stowaways, then resumed voyage.

Tankship suffered engine failure and had to drop anchor at Kecilik Bay, Turkey. This led to getting tagled with an underwater fibre-optic communication cable line, which was seriously damaged. Cable ship Antonio Meucci was appointed to investigate the incident. PERIA's departure permission was cancelled due to incomplete technical damage survey and the cable layer’s further findings. As of 6 February she was at Ambarli anchorage.
Bulk carrier suffered engine failure and lost power  at northern entrance of Istanbul Strait at Rumeli Feneri point, Turkey. Coastal Safety tug Kurtarma-2 secured her to Turkeli anchorage.

Vessel had one of drives to main propulsion broken and was unable to effect repairs due to lack of parts. She sailed at reduced speed and anchored at Lerwick anchorage on 22 January. No pollution reported.
Ferry was at risk of capsizing due to series of intense waves, during mooring manoeuvre in Bourbon, Ponza, Italy. 7 out of the 11 vehicles on board suffered damages.
Fire broke out in one of the vessel's maine engine exhaust systems, off Pouch Cove, 3.70nm of Black Head N, Canada. Crew extinguished the fire and continued voyage.
Ferry suffered a power outage while serving between Fionnphort and Iona, UK. Scheduled sailing from Iona was cancelled, while repairs were being carried out.

Crew members were alerted when smoke was noticed coming from an oven in Pasty Galley on Deck 5 Zone 6 port side, Australia. It's been confirmed that the smoke was caused by sparks in the switch panel of the oven. There was no visible fire.
Vessel allided with tailplane of Peene Bridge in S port of Wolgast, Germany. Vessel suffered only minore damages. No pollution reported. She sailed from Wolgast on 26 January.

Cargo ship suffered engine failure at Kepez point in Canakkale strait, Turkey. Coastal Safety tug Turkeli, a fast rescue boat and duty strait pilot shifted her to Bozcaada anchorage. Repairs were carried out and sailed on 23 January.
Vessel suffered main engine failure in reverse mode as she arrived at  Anchorage C, Vancouver Harbour, 1.70nm E Brockton Point, BC, Canada. Tug SAAM SABA assisted her to anchorage.

Bulk carrier was caught in strong winds while at berth at Cape Cuvier, Australia. She came slightly away from berth and while bringing her alongside shore loader allided with No.2 hatch cover forward pontoon upper edge portside.
Vessel had total loss of electrical power and propulsion, 0.46nm of Poulier de la Longue Pointe, QC, Canada. Tug assisted her to anchorage in Chenal de la Pointe-aux-Trembles.

Smoke was observed coming out from no 4 hold of the vessel during discharge operations at berth KBB4, Kwinana, Australia. Reports the smoke was most likely caused by sparks  from an excavator. The smoke was contained and there were no reported damages.
Container ship broke off her moorings in high winds of 52 knots, at Brazil Terminal Portuario, Santos, Brazil. She allided with quay without serious damages. Tugs realigned her back to quay.

The scaffolding and hoist attached to the side of the vessel collapsed at Fincantieri’s Monfalcone Shipyard in Italy, where the ship is under construction. A 23 year old contractor was trapped under the scaffolding and was rescued within 30 minutes by the Italian fire brigade. He was trasnported to the Cattinara Hospital in Trieste in critical condition. An investigation is undergoing, although the probable cause of the incident is the strong winds prevalent in the region this time of the year.

Pro Palestinian protesters organised a blockade to prevent ships from entering the Victoria International Container Terminal, Melbourne. Their target was the contaner ship ZIM GANGES which is operated by Israeli container line ZIM
Cargo ship suffered mechanical failure at Hereke, Turkey. She moved to anchorage where repairs were started. Departure is not allowed until repairs done.
Bulk carrier had technical failure at Ambarli, Turkey and departure permission was cancelled until completion of repairs. As of 20 January she was stationary at Ambarli.
Cargo ship suffered damage to internal bulkhead during loading operations at Quebec, Canada. As of 24 January she was still in Quebec.

A fire erupted in engine room, 1NM E of No.2 buoy in Qingzhou Channel near Macau, while traveling between Hong Kong and Macau, China. Crew extinguished the fire and vessel was towed to destination. No injuries reported.

A rogue wave hit the vessel off Alaska's coastline, USA, injuring 6 crew members. The incident prompted it to make an unplanned stop at Kodiak Island where it berthed on 21 January. On 24 January she continued voyage to Dutch Harbor.
Fishing trawler experienced a malfunction of the main engine turbine and lost speed in the Norwegian Sea. Vessel was towed to Murmansk for repairs.
Sailings between Digermulen and Finnvik, Norway, were cancelled due to a technical defect. Ferry Hanoy was inserted in the route.
Cargo ship had technical failure at Hereke, Turkey. Sailing was banned by HM. State surveyors will re attend vessel after repairs are finalised.

Fishing vessel ran aground off Ribadeo, Spain. Pesca 2 helicopter was dispatched to evacuate crew, while a rescue vessel refloated assisted with refloating and towed NUEVO LIBERTAD to Burela port. She had damages in keel.

Fishing vessel ELLEN BACH was struck by a floating container while she was docked in Skagen, Denmark. Skagen Rescue Station was alerted. The vessel had some scratches on hull but no other damages were reported. The container hatch was open and it sank.

American bulker was struck by a one-way drone originating from Yemeni territory, about 60nm southeast of Aden in the western Gulf of Aden. The attack was claimed by Houthi rebels. Vessel suffered a fire immediately after the attack but it was extinguished by the crew. No reports of injuries. The ship continued journey to her next scheduled port of call.

A fire erupted in engine room after the vessel left Travemunde, Germany. Tug/icebreaker VB ROENNEBECK and tug VB ARGUS towed her to Scandinavia Quay, Travemunde. A technical defect could have triggered the fire. Sailing was banned temporarily.

Two workers were killed while working at the bottom of the ship when a heavy iron plate fell on them, in Gadani shipbreaking yard, Pakistan. The National Trade Union Federation (NTUF) alleged that the workers were forced to work at the ship without adequate safety measures.
Reports vessel made bottom contact on Lichfield Shoal, 0.80nm of Duck Point, NS, Canada. She was secured in Halifax, NS. Crew assessed damages. Minor pollution reported.
Crane of vessel allided with shore crane while leaving Yokohama, Japan with tug assistance, due to strong winds. No reports on damages.
MT Zografia with 24 crew on board was reportedly sailing empty of cargo from Vietnam to Israel when it was hit by a missile off Yemen while transiting northbound in the Red Sea.
LPG tanker had damages to its propeller off Cape Race, 15.9nm of Cape Pine, NL, Canada. She proceeded to Argentia where divers were called to assess issue. Vessel was stationary as of 30 January.
Sailings serving the route Jondal - Torvikbygd, Norway were cancelled due to a technical error but they resumed the same day after rectifying issue.
A fire erupted on one of ferry's generator's belts in Quathiaski Cove. Issue was addressed abnd vessel resumed daily crossings.

Fishing vessel ran aground on rocks and listed port side, in the Sound of Sleet, Isle of Skye, after being disabled by extreme weather conditions. All crew were evacuated without any injuries. Vessel was refloated by own means with the tide rise. There were no apparent damages but she proceeded to Mallaig port for inspection by divers.

Dredger sank at berth in Mykolaiv, Ukraine, spilling petroleum into the harbour. It is uncertain why the vessel sank. As of 19 January, the petroleum concentration in the water was about 15 times the normal levels.
Vessel had technical failure at Mersin, Turkey. Sailing was banned until repairs were carried out. As of 30 January, vessel was stationary at Mersin anchorage.

STAR SABANG was caught in strong winds and high waves in the Sulu Sea, west side of Bayangan Island in Zamboanga del Nort, while en route from Cebu to Zamboanga. The cargo shifted causing the vessel to list and take in water. Philipines Coast Guard dispatched a team to evacuated the 13 crew on board the vessel. Reports say the vessel's owner will attempt towing her with the help of general cargo ship STARS DANAO.
Kuwaiti authorities reported that the cargo ship had sank at the Mina' al Ahmadi anchorage, Kuwait.
A foreign body became entangled in vessel's propeller, 2nm north of Estaca de Bares Lighthouse, Spain. Salvamar vessel Alioth towed her to Celeiro.

Vessel had main engine failure due to serious malfunction and lost speed while approaching Novorossiysk, Russia, 6.5 mi from coast. Rescue ship Merkuriy towed her and moored at Novorossiysk on 23 January.
Ferry suffered propulsion system fault and immediately after had forward engine failure, 0.58nm NNE Jack Point, BC, Canada. Tug assisted. Crew carried out repairs.

The ship's captain was arrested on suspicion of being heavily intoxicated after the ship arrived at Felixstowe, en route from Antwerp. The port pilot detected a strong smell of alcohol while guiding the ship to dock and reported it to the port authority. The captain was found to be almost four times the legal limit for seafarers. Vessel left Felixtowe on 16 January, bound for Turkey.

Submersible Ran, which was operated from icebreaker Araon, disappeared in January 2024 during a dive. It was collecting close-up imaging and data of the Thwaites’ underside when the researchers lost contact. The machine never resurfaced at its pre-programmed return point. A search operation was launched using acoustic search equipment, helicopters, and drones, but without success. As of 15 February ARAON was back at Lyttleton, New Zealand.

Houthi rebels fired an unidentified projectile towards vessel while she was transitting the RSEA. "As a result of the impact, the vessel suffered limited damage to a cargo hold but is stable and is heading out of the area,” the Stamford company said on Monday in a prepared release. “All seafarers onboard the vessel are confirmed to be uninjured. The vessel is carrying a cargo of steel products.”
Vehicles carrier was NUC due to engine failure, 9nm from Brighton Windfarm, UK. Repairs to main engine hydraulics were completed and vessel continued voyage.

A crew member was evacuated by the CCS Gijón section of Salvamento Marítimo. The Salvamar Rigel transferred the patient to the pilot dock where an ambulance took him to hospital for medical assistance.

Reports vessel had an oil leak in Charlottetown, Price Edward Island, Canada, while en route to a scrapyard in India. Divers checked the ship's hull but did not find any damages or leaks. It was believed that the leak could have come from a compromised fuel tank. A boom was placed around the vessel and the owner committed to emptying the tank to prevent any further leaks.

A water pipe burst on board the vessel and water rained down from the ceiling and onto a pick-up truck on vehicel deck, in Nanaimo, Canada. Repairs were carried out and departure was delayed for about 40 minutes.

Vessel allided with ferry quay at Kvamsoya, More and Romsdal county, Norway, while serving as replacement for ferry OS .No injuries were reported. She was towed by tug Bukken to Vegsund Slip for repairs.
Vessel suffered mechanical failure at the South entrance of Istanbul Strait at Sarayburnu. She shifted to Yenikapi anchorage under own power and sailed on 19 January.
Cargo ship experienced technical failure, sheltered and dropped anchor at Gerze anchorage, Turkey. Repairs were done by crew and the ship sailed from Gerze on 16 January.

Ferry SOGNDAL, returning from tourist cruise in Mostraumen,  collided with passenger vessel FJORDBRIS at Strand Quay terminal in Vagen/Bergen, Norway. SOGNDAL suffered a technical fault and circled Vagen for a short while before attempting to dock.
Vessel was NUC due to engine failure, about 23 nm from N. Foreland remote radio site, UK. She started drifting towards French waters. She was assisted to berth at Dunkirk on 16 January.
Cargo vessel suffered engine failure off Skikda, Algeria. Crew was not able to repair. Tug Christos XXIV towed her to Kas, Turkey for repairs.
Tanker allided with rubber of No.3 jetty fender at Kingbay BLB Jetty, Dampier, Australia. Only minor damages to rubber of terminal fender were reported.

Ferry SOGNDAL, returning from tourist cruise in Mostraumen,  collided with passenger vessel FJORDBRIS at Strand Quay terminal in Vagen/Bergen, Norway. FJORDBRIS was sent to shipyard in Leirvikand resumed sailings on 22 January.

A crew member suffered severe abdominal pains, 10 miles south of Galveston, Texas. An MH-65 Dolphin helicopter crew from USCG Air Station transported the man to the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston in stable condition.
Bulk carrier suffered engine fault off Cuxuaven, Germany. Support vessel Neuwerk and tugs Wulf 5 and Fairplay-35 assisted. Vessel berthed in Hansaport of Hamburg.

Dock stay was extended due to an issue with propeller shaft at Svendborg, Denmark. Sailings between Aero and Langeland were suspended. Repairs were done at port of Randers and was expected to resume operations on 24 January.

A crew member was medevaced by an SAR Helimer 215 helicopter 88nm southeast of Cartagena, Spain, while en route from Antwerp to Port Said. The man was taken to Alicante airport, where he received medical assistance.
Vessel was sidelined after one of the engines could not be started in Bronnoysund, Norway. Ferry resumed sailings the next day after the starter motor on engine was changed.
Ferry experienced mechanical failure and was sidelined in Breivika, Norway for troubleshooting. Ferry KVAM replaced the vessel on the route Larsnes Aram - Voksa - Kvamsoya.
Reports vessel had a minor bottom contact in off Mikkels Havn, Denmark. She was examined by divers after arrival in the port of Korsor. No damages or injuries reported.
Tug's towing winch failed while towing a barge in Strait of Georgia off Campbell River, BC, Canada. Another tug was deployed to tow. Crew carried out repairs.

Cargo ship ran aground on a coral reef near Samalona Island, Makassar City, South Sulawesi, Indonesia, en route from Makassar to Jakarta. The local port authority deployed two tugs which helped refloating the ship. An investigation was launched to determine the cause of the incident and to assess damages to the reef.
Vessel's port side stern hit the ramp of the Quay No. 15 while departing from Tallinn to Helsinki. She had damage to the stern above the waterline, but could remain in service.
A rope got entangled in the vessel's propeller at Kjeringa in Ryfylke, Norway. 5 departures were cancelled.

Tug ran aground while towing a barge loaded with containers at Selegi reef, Singapore Western anchorage. She was refloated with high tide by local tugs and berthed at Pasir Panjang Terminal on 14 January.

Vessel which has been moored at the port of Maputo, Mozambique since April 29th 2023, was detained due to unpaid fees to servicing companies and to the port of Maputo. 30 crew members from Russia, Ukraine and Lithuania are still on board waiting to be repatriated. Their countries' embassies have been engaged in negotiations with local authoritites for over three months.
Vessel had engine fault, lost power and started drifting at Rumelifeneri point of Istanbul Strait. Repairs could not carried out by crew.

Ferry suffered damages to engine exhaust system while en route from Dafni to Ouranopolis, Greece. The 15 passengers on board the vessel were disembarked at Ouranopolis. Sailing was banned until repairs were carried out.

Vehicles carrier suffered fuel pump failurein North Pacific Ocean, BC, Canada. She resumed voyage using remaining fuel pumps. Repairs were carried out at the port of Tacoma and she sailed on 26 January.

An outbreak of norovirus abord the vessel was confirmed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). 68 out of the 2056 passengers reported symptoms of vomitting and diarrhoea which exceeded the 2% threshold mandating a report to the CDC’s Vessel Sanitation Programme. Also 7 out 948 crew members reported similar symptoms. Sanitation measures were implemented together with isolation of the affected individuals.
Ferry's sailings between Mallaig and Armadale, UK were cancelled due to ongoing issues with the bow thruster. An engineer attended and carried out investigations. Issue resolved.

A fire erupted in the engine room at the port of Piombino, Italy. The crew, together with the Piombino fire brigade extinguished the fire within one hour. The fire was caused by diesel leak from one of the generators which caught fire and extended to the general power supply cables, causing a system blackout. No reports of injuries.
Master of vessel reported an increase in temperature in No.4 bearing of port main engine, during a test voyage to Piraeus. Sailing was banned until repairs were carried out.

Reports vessel collided with another vessel after entering southern lock, Kiel Canal, Kiel-Holtenau,Germany. An investigation was initiated while vessel was still inside lock. She then arrived at Remontowa Shipyard, Gdansk, Poland on 14 January. Sailed from Gdansk on 27 February.

Oil products tanker was arrested at Pennington oil field for allegedly transporting illegal crude oil from offshore Sokebolou Field base in Bayelsa State. The captain declared that the vessel's owner lured him and his crew under the pretence that they were heading for Bayelsa State to load a cargo of diesel and transport it to Lagos
Dirty ballast water leaked into sea water at Antalya, Turkey, during loading operations. A pollution fine was imposed and an investigation was underway.

Vessel experienced problems with sensor on one of the 4 engines while sailing from Wellington, New Zealand. There was no loss of propulsion, so she continued via Northern Entrance and arrived in Picton the same day.
Cruise ship drifted in strong currents and ran aground, near Buoy No 2, during tendering Tender 13, just outside Rhyll marina. Awaiting for high tide to refloat safely.
Bulk carrier suffered main hydraulic line failure on its windlass upon arrival to anchorage in English Bay, 3.80 NM SE of Point Atkinson, BC, Canada. She dropped anchor and crew carried out repairs.

A forklift overturned  on board the vehicles carrier during cargo operations at Bremerhaven, Germany. A crew member died after being trapped under the forklift. Police started an investigation. The vessel sailed from port on 12 January.

Two passengers aboard the cruise ship were charged with Conspiracy to Possess with Intent to Distribute a Controlled Substance and Possession with Intent to Distribute a Controlled Substance, after a drug-sniffing dog detected a total of 71.9 kgs of marijuana leaf in 56 vacuum-sealed bags. The drugs were found shortly before the vessel's scheduled voyage from Miami, Florida, to Southampton, UK.

Vessel suffered engine failure while en route from Fukuyama, Japan, to Busan, South Korea. She dropped anchor nearby Fukuyama. Assistance was requested when a crew member went missing, probably lost overboard. SAR operation is ongoing.

Ferry suffered angine failure and was towed to Fjellstrand AS shipyard in Omastranda, Norway for repairs. Sailings were cancelled for the rest of the day and reserve ferry Lifjord was introduce to replace. SILDAFJORD sailed from Omastranda on 21 January.
Vessel had engine failure at Valletta, Malta. Tug SEA VANQUISH towed her to Yalova shipyard. A Coastal Safety Tug was to escort during Cannakkale Strait.
Inland tanker allided with a pole on starboard side steering her into strong current, in Kampen, Netherlands. She drifted and barely avoided hitting bridge.

Fishing vessel ran aground on beach of Dieppe, France after she suffered an engine failure. She allided with pier before coming to rest on pebbles. She was refloated the next day and had significant impact marks on front of the hull.
Ferry allided with artificial rocks that border one of piers of Villa San Giovanni landing place, soon after leaving the port, due to engine issues. She sailed the same day.
A small amount of oil leaked into the port waters of Fukuyama during refuelling from a tanker. An investigation was ongoing and as of 12 January the vessel remained stationary in the port.
Container ship ran aground onto shallows in Mizushima Port, Japan. She was soon refloated by own means and moored at the port.

Bulk carrier allided with a fender while berthing at Shuaiba Port, Kuwait. She suffered damages to the bulbous bow. Awaiting further instructions from port authorities after cargo discharge operations.

The cruise ship is another vessel that had to alter her course in the Red Sea due to geopolitical tensions in the area. She was scheduled to pass through Bab El-Mandeb as part of her journey from Jordan to Oman, but it was decided to sail towards Sharm El Sheikh at the southern end of the Sinai Peninsula, then to Ain Sukhna and Safaga in Egypt, ultimately set to disembark all its passengers in Aqaba, Jordan.
MSC MINA had to stop and drop anchor 38nm from Margate, UK due to engine failure which was caused by low fuel temperature. Problem was solved and continued voyage.
Fishing vessel suffered mechanical failure and started drifting 15nm North of La Galea, Spain. Salvamar vessel Alcyone was dispatched and towed vessel to the port of Laredo.

Ferry was caught in adverese weather in the sea area of the new Drapetsonas pier, broke off her moorings and allided with passenger/RoRo cargo ship Smyrna di Levante. The Port Authority of Keratsini banned sailings until sea worthiness certificate was provided. No injuries or pollution reported.

Ferry AGIOS GEORGIOS was caught in adverese weather in the sea area of the new Drapetsonas pier, broke off her moorings and allided with SMYRNA DI LEVANTE. The Port Authority of Keratsini banned sailings until sea worthiness certificate was provided. No injuries or pollution reported.

Ferry was caught in rough weather en route from Anacortes to Mukilteo and suffered extensive water ingress in car deck. There were no injuried reported and the damages were minimal thus the service remained unaffected.
Ferry ALCANTARA DOS broke off her moorings in strong winds at new Drapetsonas pier, Greece and collided with ferry SAONISOS which was pushed against SUPERSTAR II. No reports on damages.

The cargo on board barge Hanalei shifted while the barge was towed by the tug, in Strait of Georgia off Richmond, 7.70NM SSW Point Atkinson, Canada. The barge was intentionally grounded off Point Grey.
Cement carrier suffered engine failure 10 NM W of Kalymnos, Greece. She was detained until port authority inspected and sailed Kalymnos on 11 January.
Ferry ALCANTARA DOS broke off her moorings in strong winds at new Drapetsonas pier, Greece and collided with ferry SAONISOS which was pushed against SUPERSTAR II. No reports on damages.
Ferry ALCANTARA DOS broke off her moorings in strong winds at new Drapetsonas pier, Greece and collided with ferry SAONISOS which was pushed against SUPERSTAR II. No reports on damages.
Container ship suffered engine failure while berthing at at Roberts Bank, Canada with tugs' assistance. She moved to an anchorage in English Bay to assess the issue.

A fire erupted in the engine room, off the coast of Silivri, Turkey, heading to Marmara Sea. Two crew members suffered injuried and were evacuated by the Coast Guard ship CSG 312. Several tugs were nearby. As of 11 January vessel was at Tuzla Anchorage and listed as NUC.

UPDATE: 12-Mar-2024 The Philippines' Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) stated that they had reached an agreement with Iran to have the crewmembers released, with the agreement that the Philippine Government sends other crewmembers to take their place. Iran asserted that the crew members were never held hostage but that they were serving their contracts aboard the ship. They will be released at the end of their contracts. UPDATE: 21-Feb-2024 The Philippines Undersecretary confirmed that one of the 18 Filipino crew members was released earlier this month and said that the authorities are working towards releasing others. No other details were shared about the crew member. Greece has also gotten their national released ten days after the vessel was seized. Iranian Force seized the vessel as retaliation for the 2023 case when US confiscated a cargo of Iranian oil destined for China. She was en route from the Al Basrah terminal in Iraq to Aliaga, Turkey. On board there are 18 Filipino crew and one Greek.

Bulk carrier has been detained by the Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency for illegally anchoring 15nm west of Kuala Muda. The master of the vessel failed to produce documents showing that the vessel was allowed to berth in Langkawi. As of 11 January vessel was anchored in the Malacca Strait.
A crew member suffered a head injury while en route from Fort de France, Martinique, to Puerto Quetzal, Guatemala. The man had to be medevaced to Fort de France for further medical care.
Vessel's CO2 firefighting system suffered a leak in St. Lawrence River off St-Simeon, Quebec, Canada. She proceeded to Quebec for repairs and sailed on 10 January.
Vessel was caught in rough weather and lost her evacuation chute which caused a hull tear, in North Sea, UK. She was towed by tugs Atlantic Merlin and Loke Viking.

A fire erupted on board the vessel at the Barbours Cut Container Terminal, Port Houston. The port Fire Department attended and extinguished the fire and will continue to monitor the ship as a safety measure. Two crew members have died in the fire and a third one was medevaced to hospital. An investigation is underway.
Tanker suffered a mechanical failure which required emergency repairs. She berthed at shipyard of Harland and Wolff, Belfast, UK. As of 23 Januray vessel was still at Belfast.

The second engineer on board the vessel lost his life during a boiler explosion in the engine room, in the Mediterranean, en route to Italy. Following the explosion Italian Port Authorities and Ankara MRCC were contacted to arrange a medical evacuation but the man died before they arrived. An investigation into the cause of the incident is undergoing.

Jamaican police were called at Kingston port after the chief engineer was found dead in his cabin, foaming at both corners of his mouth. There were no signs of violence. An investigation into the death is ongoing.
Ferry allided with with the quay while entering Wadomari Port on Okinoerabu Island, Kagoshima, Japan. Reports say the accident was caused by engine failure. There were no injuries or oil spills.
Ferry entangled a buoy chain in a propeller while leaving Port of Casamicciola Terme, Italy due to strong winds. She berthed at Casamicciola and sailed the next day.

Ferry's sailings were disrupted after smoke was noticed in the passenger lounge, en route from Fishbourne. Vessel berthed at Portsmouth  where all passengers disembarked, and all vehicles were evacuated. The local fire and rescue service attented and discovered that the smoke came from an electrical light. Three sailings were cancelled and all booked passengers were offered alternative sailings.
Experinced a technical failure during Istanbul Strait passage at Cape Yenikoy Point, Turkiye, requiring tug and pilot assistance, she successfully sailed the next day.
Small fire occurred in the engine room at Ravenna, Italy, It was extinguished by authorities. It will remain in port until restoration work is done.
Experienced a technical failure in Zonguldak, Turkiye, leading to the cancellation of departure permission and crew repairs, causing the ship to sail a few days later.
Main engine failure occurred while preparing to depart Vancouver, Canada, leading to the vessel proceeding to Vancouver Inner Anchorage and sailing the next day.
Ferry had engine fault 8 nm West of Jersey coast, France and she had to turn back. She docked  in Cherbourg and resumed sailings on  10 January.

LPG tanker was NUC due to engine alarm issues, 26.8 nm of St Catherine's Light, IOW, UK. Crew was required to change exhaust valve. Repairs took about three hours. Vessel arrived in Sines on 10 January.
Fishing vessel suffered water ingress through the discharge valve, 12 feet below water line, off Labrador coast. She seeked refuge near Black Tickle, Canada, and sailed to St. John's on 10 January.
Collision occurred with the chemical tanker Easterly AS Omaria in Becancour, Canada, causing damage to navigational lights and requiring repairs.

Ferry ran aground on a reef in Lomaloma on her journey to Suva, Fiji. The incident was attributed to the captain's inexperience with navigating the unmarked reefs of Lau. Engineers have been disaptched to asses the damages and carry out repairs.
Ferry was stuck in ice for several hours at exit of Vanino, Russia. Passenger ro/ro vessel Alexandr Deev assisted. SAKHALIN-9 arrived in Vanino on 8 January.

Passenger ship had engine failure at Fethiye, Turkey and couldn't be repaired by crew or local technicians. Tug Ramazan Bey towed her to Yalova for permanent repairs. As of 28 February she was stationary at Yalova.
Guests experienced extended cruise due to reduced speed forced by propulsion issues, causing a delay in their return to Miami, USA, Engineers were working to resolve the issue.
An electrical fire erupted in ballast pump at Lennox Passage, Nova Scotia, 0.67NM NW of Drinkwaters Head, Canada. Repairs were carried out by crew.
Cruise ship was caught in tornado-like winds and broke off her moorings in Siracusa, Italy. She allided with the dock and drifted against Siracusa Marina Yachting with several pleasure boats.
Experienced a major engine failure, causing vessel to be moored for investigation before sailing from Quebec, Canada.
Tanker suffered engine failure at S. entrance of Canakkale Strait, Turkey. She was towed to Bozcaada Island anchorage, as crew couldn't repair. Sailing was banned until repairs are done.

Tanker SUNDORO had engine failure at Gocuk point in strait, Turkey. She anchored at Sevketiye anchorage under supervision of tug Kurtarma 15. A fine was imposed and sailing was banned until the next day, when the repairs were done.
Collision with another barge and damages occurred at Chittagong Outer Anchorage, Bangladesh, temporary repairs were conducted and she sailed to Mongla. Also later sailed from Mongla.

Five military personnel went missing after apprehending the vessel off the coast of Senegal, Africa. Reports say the vessel was loaded with a large quantity of narcotic substances and was intentionally sunk by the drug traffickers on board.
Ferry had mechanical failure and cancelled sailing between Langnas and Kokar, Finland. A taxi boat assisted.
Vessel had technical issue with generator and sailings on route Tayinloan-Gigha, UK, were suspended. The ferry operator was in process of sourcing required spare parts to carry out repairs.
Cargo ship had technical failure at Ceyhan, Turkey. Vessel shifted to anchorage area for repairs and sailed on 10 January, bound for Yalova.
Vehicles carrier suffered engine failure at Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. Crew couldn't carry out repairs. Tug Blasco towed her to Yalova shipyard, Turkey on 28 January.
Four stowaways were arrested by the Nigerian Navy at the Lagos Fairway Buoy, as they were trying to flee to Europe on board the vessel.
Tanker was NUC after having a small water leakage in boiler, about 50 nm South of Scilly Isles, UK. Repairs were carried out and continued voyage the same day.

Cruise ship had to alter route and circumvent the Red Sea due to security concerns in the area, involving missile attacks by Houthi Rebels. All passengers were assured that most of the planned stops were still part of the itinerary.
Ferry suffered water ingress in aft void space and cancelled sailings between Tarbert to Portavadie, UK to carry out repairs.

The cruise ship broke off her moorings during strong winds, while debarking passengers in Galveston, Texas. Debarkation was suspended and gangways were closed temporarily. She was quickly secured since she didn't break completely freee. No injuries were reported. As of 7 January vessel was en route from Costa Maya, Mexico to Belize City, Belize.
Vessel suffered engine failure while sailing between Edoya and Sandvika, Netherlands. A lifeboat assisted her to berth. She was taken out of service for repairs.
Vessel ran aground off Kerteminde port, Denmark. On 11 January, tug Goliath Vig refloated her with the help of strong tow wire and high tide. Vessel was then towed to Svendborg for inspection.
Ice breaker has broken down in Parnu, Estonia. Repair workers from Finland were brough on board. No given estimate for the duration of repairs.
Ferry's sailings between Tayinloan and Gigha, UK were temporarily cancelled after having issues with the aft ramp, which required repairs. Service was resumed the same day.

Container ship had engine problems on Western Scheldt, Netherlands at buoy 40. She anchored using bow thruster only. Tugs Bravo, Multratug 1 and Multratug 7 assisted and then tugs VB Pearl abd VB Victory towed her to Deurganckdok, Belgium.
Tanker suffered mechanical failure at Taman, Russia. Crew carried out repairs and departure permission was give on 13 January.
A fire erupted on terrace of a cabin at Quai des Tourelles, in port of Fort-de-France, Martinique. The crew brought fire under control and vessel continued journey same day. No reports of injuries.
Cargo ship was NUC due to an engine failure 8.7nm from Calvay Lighthouse, while en route from Warrenpoint, UK to Oslo, Norway. Repairs were carried out by crew and resumed voyage the same day.

UPDATE: On 5 January, the vessel was successfully boarded by a team of Elite Indian Navy commandos, prompting the pirates to flee. An armed group boarded the vessel some 850km off the coast of Somalia, southeast of Eyl, Somalia. The duty officer spotted the intruders and the crew members were able to reach the citadel. Given the location of the incident, pirates were likely to blame.
Ferry suffered mechanical failure and sailings on between Bodo, Vaeroy and Moskenes were cancelled. She left Bodo the next day after repairs.

Reports that te vessel has been attacked in the Indian Ocean northwest of the Maldives and near the port of Kochi, just 48 hours after the assassination of Saleh al-Aaruri, the deputy head of the Hamas political bureau. As of 10 January she was at Mangalore Anchorage, west India.

Reports that te vessel has been attacked in the Indian Ocean northwest of the Maldives and near the port of Kochi, just 48 hours after the assassination of Saleh al-Aaruri, the deputy head of the Hamas political bureau. As of 10 January, she was en route from Kandla to the Suez Canal.
Cargo ship experienced mechanical failure at Aliaga, Turkey. She shifted to anchorage for repairs. Departure permission was granted on 9 January and sailed to Izmail, Ukraine.
Vessel suffered mechanical failure at Gemlik, Turkey. Crew carried out repairs and sailed from Gemlik on 6 January.

Ferry was prevented to dock in the North port, while en route from Oslo to Copenhagen, due to severe weather conditions. Tug FRIGGA was deployed to assist but had to give up. Also, a person on board had to be medevaced by a military rescue helicopter due to falling ill.
Cargo ship had heavy list to starboard in the Black Sea. On 18 January she was towed and anchored off Cide, but lost power, dragged anchor and ran aground in Cide shallows on 20 January.

FRIENDLAND was trapped by ice in strong winds and came to a standstill in Estonian waters. A ferry successfully opened a channel to the ship and escorted it to open waters, enabling the vessel to resume her journey back to Finland.

BUGOE was caught in rough weather conditions nearby Estonia and was stranded in shallow waters on the edge of the Väinameri bay. Local tug attempted to refloat but wasn't able due to the weather conditions. Awaiting to refloat with tide and for weather to improve.

Rostock water police found that the bulk carrier used banned high sulphur fuel within the emissions control area, on her way to Rostock, Germany. Proceedings against the captain and chief engineer were initiated.

Three individuals approached the vessel in a canoe while she was anchored at Luanda Anchorage, Angola. They stole some of the ship's properties and fled. The theft was only discovered the next morning.
Bulk carrier had engine trouble at entrance of Suez Canal from Mediterranean Sea. 11 vessels were held behind. The following day ACRA anchored 2.3NM from Suez Canal S Anchorage, Egypt.
NEZHA suffered mechanical failure at Iskenderun, Turkey. Departure permission was temporarily cancelled. She sailed on 6 January after repairs were completed.
Vessel experienced technical failure at Bartin, Turkey. Repairs were completed and she sailed from Bartin on 3 January.
Vessel ran aground in the Mariager Fjord, Denmark. She was refloated and inspected the same day and continued voyage. Further inspections will be carried out at port of destination.

A fishing vessel's captain informed the Port Authority of Kalymnos, Grece that they have allided with the aggregates carrier, which was detained and anchored off the port of Kalymnos. It seems that BLUE SHARK did not have her mooring-deck lights on. The incident caused damages to both vessels and an investigation was on. No reports of injuries or pollution.
Ferry encountered technical issues in rough weather and her service from Castlebay to Oban, UK was delayed. Issue was fixed and resumed sailings the next day.
Cargo ship had to shift from Ambarli port to an anchorage due to a technical fault that required repairs. She sailed on 5 January.

The 9,385-teu CMA CGM Tage (built 2015) was targeted by Houthi militants while en route from Singapore to Alexandria, Egypt on the evening of 2 January. Up to three explosions were noticed near the vessel towards its portside quarter, 15 miles (24 km) southwest of Mocha in Yemen, according to Vesseltracker. The attack was confirmed by the Houthi militia in a statement on social media channel X claiming that the vessel was “travelling toward the ports of occupied Palestine”.
Bulk carrier allided with wharf and iron ore export facility whil berthing at Port Hedland, Australia. She suffered some damages and sailed on 4 January, after assessments.

Bulk carrier allided with wooden fendering surrounding CSX Railroad bridge, at St.Joseph Harbour, US, due to issues with bow thruster. No reports of injuries, pollution or damages to vessel. She was freed and sailed the same day.
Ferry's sailings from Langnas, Sweded were cancelled due to technical issues. She sailed from Langnasudd on 8 January.

A fire erupted in the engine room, in the Arabian Sea, while en route from Nhava Sheva to Jebel Ali, UAE. Indian Coast Guard patrol ship SARTHAK assisted with firefighting, and reported that fire was under control. All crew were safe.

Reports vessel has been boarded by perpetrators, off Malabo, as she was heading for the Doula Port, Cameroon. The master and chief engineer have been abducted, although there are reports that nine crew members were kidnapped in total. So far there has been no contact from the missing crew or their captors.

Vehicles carrier was sent back to South Korea after the “yellow-spotted stink bug” was found on board, in Australia. Only a few Tesla vehicles were offloaded after they were checked for vermin. The rest had to be returned to ports in China and South Korea.

Tanker allided with the pier at the port of Mikron Vathy in Chalkis, Greece, during mooring operations. She suffered a crack on the starboard side above the waterline and was banned from sailing until class maintenance certificate was issued.
Vessel engine telegraph failure, about 2.5nm SE of Panther Point, in Trincomali Channel, Canada. The system was restarted and resumed voyage.

According to a statement by US Central Command (Centcom), the 15,300-teu Maersk Hangzhou (built 2018) came under attack at about 1730 GMT on 30 December, somewhere in the southern Red Sea. The vessel “reported that they were struck by a missile” and “requested assistance”.

Migrnt rescue ship was detained in the port of Bari for 20 days after failing to proceed directly to port after a rescue. The vessel received an alert regarding a boat in distress 15 miles away as she was heading to Bari and diverted to rescue 70 more people, going against a law that requires vessels to proceeed direct to port after migrants have been rescued.
Vessel suffered engine failure North off Karasu, Turkey, in the Black Sea. Tug Kocabas 1 towed her the next day. As of 2 February she was stationary at Zonguldak. Repairs in progress.

A fire broke out in the engine room off the coast of Badishijima, Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan. The vessel was disabled and was towed to Kagoshima Port the next day. An investigation into the cause of the fire was started. No reports of injuries.

A fire erupted on board the vessel at port of Krabozavodskoye, Shikotan Island, Russia, which covered and area of 24 cubic metres at stern of vessel. The fire was promptly extinguished and there were no injuried reported.

Fishing vessel suffered mechanical failure due to fouled propeller. The crew were unable to conduct repairs and the vessel started drifting approx 575 miles SW of Dutch Harbour,US. Coast Guard Cutter Alex Haley towed her to Adak and moored at the pier on 1 January.
Ferry suffered mechanical failure in oil pump of port side main engine at Kalymnos, Greece. No reports of injuried or pollution. Sailings were cancelled until repairs.
Cargo ship had engine failure at Monfalcone Anchorage, Italy. Crew were unable to repair. Tug Horoz towed vessel and moored at Yalova, Turkiey on 14 January for repairs.
Vessel allided with wharf upon arrival in La Grande Anse, QC, Canada, while assisted by tug FJORD ETERNITE. She suffered hull damages but was able to sail on the next day.

UPDATE: 11-Feb-2024 GENIUS STAR XI left Dutch Harbor bound for San Diego, California. The Unified Command managing the incident has stood down and all response operations have been completed. The vessel continued its voyage after it secured all cargo and completed a Coast Guard Port State Control inspection. A fire erupted on board the vessel carrying lithium-ion batteries, 225 miles southwest of Dutch Harbor, Alaska. The Coast Guard directed vessel towards Dutch Harbor while an HC-130 airplane and the Coast Guard Cutter Alex Haley were dispatched to provide assistance. No reports of injuries or pollution.
A major rescue operation was initiated at Boulogne Sur-Mer, France after the fishing vessel reported significant water ingress. Vessel was safely secured at Boulogne after several hours of pumping.
Fishing vessel had engine blackout about 7nm North of Grenen, Denmark. Lifeboat Lars Kruse towed her to Skagen. Smaller lifeboat FRB08 also assisted.

Container ship suffered main engine cooling system failure in the St. Lawrence River off Portneuf, Canada. She was anchored for repairs and resumed voyage the same day. Arrived in Halifax on 30 December.
Ferry had a technical issue and service between Uig and Tarbert, UK was postponed. All routes were delayed.
Ferry collided with a tug on departure from the port of Genova. She returned to port to carry out technical checks and sailed on the next day.

Inland tanker got wedged between bridge and dam on Main at Mainz-Kostheim lock, Germany. She was pulled out and moored at Kostheim lock. She suffered minor damages like scratch marks and paint abrasion.

Two seafarers were injured early on Wednesday when VYSSOS hit a mine in the Black Sea as it headed to load grain at a port on the Danube river. The explosion started a fire on the upper deck. “The ship lost speed and control, a fire broke out on the upper deck. To avoid flooding, the captain anchored the ship aground,”
Vessel experienced engine failure off Karaburun N entrance, Istanbul Strait. Tug AYAZBEY assisted and shifted to Yalova shipyard area.

Tanker suffered a blackout in front of old ferry port Terneuzen, Netherlands. Multratug 13, Multratug 7 and VB Triumphante towed her to well of Terneuzen. Awaiting for parts necessary to fix the problem.
Reports that a fire erupted on board vessel in Mozambique Channel, en route from Cape Town to Dar-es-Salaam. Crew attempted to extinguished fire but failed and abandoned ship into life rafts.

Three stowaways were found in the rudder compartment at Lagos roadstead. They had boarded the vessel with some fishermen's assisstance. They have been arrested by the Nigerian Navy Ship Beecroft and  handed to the Nigerian Immigration Service for necessary action.
A fire erupted in the wheelhouse due to an electric short circuit, while under repairs at Tripoli port, Libya. The fire was extinguished but destroyed wheelhouse equipment and three cabins.
Vessel experienced a technical failure at Sugozu, Turkey and departure permission temporarily cancelled until repairs. She sailed Sugozu on 28 December.

Fire erupted  in engine room in Bay of Biscay SW of Brest, while en route from Immingham to Turkey. Crew managed to put out the fire but couldn't restart engine. Turkish media reported that the crew requested evacuation as they were unable to carry out repairs due to rough weather. The vessel's management company, however, declared that the ship is not abandoned. According to AIS track vessel is under tow.

An explosion occured on board due to an electrical failure while docked at  the port of Mombasa ,around the Liwatoni area. The fire was extinguished within an hour by KPA harbour tug SIMBHA III. A crew member suffered a minor head injury and he was taken to hospital.

An oil spill was detected while vessel was mooring at underwater loading buoy off Puerto Rosales oil port abt 30 KMS SE of port city of Bahia Blanca, Argentina. The oil slick was at least 21 square kilometres.

MSC Mediterranean Shipping Company has confirmed that one of its container ships was attacked on Tuesday while transiting the southern Red Sea. A statement from the group confirmed earlier claims made by Yemen’s Houthi rebels that they had attacked 8,204-teu MSC United VIII (built 2006) at approximately 12:25 UTC. The Liberia-flagged ship was en route from King Abdullah Port, Saudi Arabia to Karachi, Pakistan.

Damage was observed in bow centre of vessel and had to be taken out of service in Ronne, Denmark. Ferries Hammershus and Express 1 took over sailings. Damage likely occurred in a recent storm. Repair status and sailing permission unknown.

For individuals armed with long knives boarded the vessel at the Dumai anchorage, eastern Sumatra. They took the duty seaman hostage, while the onboard shore security watchman fled when they threathened him with knives. The duty engineer raised the alarm and the robbers fled with some stolen engine spares.

PEARL KENZO collided with a fishing vessel near Chengshan Jiao in China, while en route from Penglai in Northern China to Zhoushan. The fishing vessel sank and eight crew members were reported missing. The China Maritime Safety Administration initiated a search and rescue operation.
Vessel had technical failure, sheltered and dropped anchor at Cesme anchorage, while en route from Nemrut Bay to Mersin, Turkey. Crew carried out repairs and sailed from Cesme on 27 December.

SAR vessel suffered engine failure and started drifting at harbour entrance in Hvide Sande, Denmark, while en route to assist a crab boat. Crew couldn't repair. A rescue team was deployed via helicopter, fixed engine and vessel returned to harbour.

The Antwerp port authority received a phone bomb threat, claiming that there was a bomb in a car on board the vessel, as she was heading for Antwerp. The ship had left Hamburg the previous day. A search was conducted and no bomb was found.

Passengers on board the vessel spotted several people wearing lifejackets and alerted the crew. The cruise ship altered her course to initiate search and rescue operations and also notified Indian Coast Guard, which arrived a few hours later and assumed control of the search and rescue mission. Five fishermen were rescued and transported to Mumbai Hospital for medical care. They were in stable condition.

A crew member suffered a serious injury 70nm northeast of La Isleta, Spain and was in need of immediate medical attention. CCS Las Palmas of Salvamento Marítimo deployed an SAR helicopter which airlifted the man and transferred him to Las Palmas airport for further medical care.

Container ship allided with container crane on arrival at North Sea Terminal at Scheldelaan 602 in Berendrechtin port of Antwerp, Belgium. The crane toppled over and collapsed onto the quay. No injuries were reported.

The captain fell sick and was in need of urgent medical assistance 2.5nm southeast of the small Baltic Sea island of Greifswalder Oie. Lifeboat Berthold Beitzwas deployed to assist and, despite the adverse weather conditions, managed to transfer two sea rescuers onto the vessel to provide first aid. The man was eventually medevaced by helicopter and taken to hospital.
Ferry had a power generator issue, which needed to be addressed in Tayinloan, UK. The service between Tayinloan and Gigha was cancelled for the rest of the day.

Fire broke out in living quarters of vessel but  was extinguished by city firefighting teams. No information on damages, no other details given. Vessel was stationed in Murmansk, Russian at the time of incident.
While vessel was berthed in Kaohsiung, fire broke out in the engine room. Some 8 fire engines responded, fire was extinguished before noon, no injures reported, extent of damages unknown.

Central Command said that earlier in the day, the 33,600-dwt chemical and tanker Blaamanen (built 2004) reported a near-miss by a similar kamikaze drone. There were no injuries or damage as a result of the attack.
Ferry's sailings were cancelled until 28 December after suffering main engine failure. The engine turbo charger needed to be replaced.

The captain requested medical assistance for a crew member who had falled ill, while 7nm from the coast of Cartagena, en route from Tarragona to Horsens. A vessel from MRCC of Salvamento Marítimo evacuated the man and took him to the port where he was picked by an ambulance and transferred to hospital.

A Defense Department official said the 21,300-dwt chemical tanker Chem Pluto (built 2012) was hit by a “one-way attack drone fired from Iran” while it was 200 nautical miles (370 km) off the Indian coast, according to multiple press reports.
Tug collided with a fishing vessel 29nm from Vietnam coast. The fishing vessel sank and the crew was rescued by two other fishing vessels. The tug sailed towards Indonesia.

Vessel suffered an explosion in cargo hold, about 40nm WSW of St Annes Head, UK, en route from Dublin, Ireland to Ijmuiden, Netherlands. MRCC Milford Haven monitored the vessel’s progress until the ship arrived at Avonmouth in the Bristol Channel.

https://www.livemint.com/news/world/mv-sai-baba-with-indian-crew-among-other-multiple-ships-attacked-by-houthi-drone-in-red-sea-heres-what-we-know-so-far-11703397512493.html M/V SAIBABA, a Gabon-owned, Indian-flagged crude oil tanker, reported that it was hit by a one-way attack drone with no injuries reported.
Vessel ran aground in St. Marys River, Great Lakes, after suffering blackout. She is en route from Thunder Bay to Port Cartier.
Ferry lost propulsion power aboutt 7.80 NM W of La Longue Pointe, in the St. Lawrence River after departure from Matane, Canada.  Crew carried out repairs and resumed voyage.
Intense vibrations were noticed aboard the vessel and had to be docked for inspection. Her service between Seattle and Bremerton resumed on 26 December.
Tug experienced mechanical failure during Canakkale Strait passage, en route from Nemrut Bay to Tuzla, Turkey. She dropped anchor at Karanlik Liman Anchorage and crew started repairs.

Vessel was pushed onto a quay wall at the Neuharlingersiel ferry terminal in the Wittmund district, Germany, during the storm Pia. The grounding happened during flooding, leaving the vessel high and dry.

Reports that vessel lost 46 containers off Northern Jutland coast in Skagerrak, while en route from Bremerhaven to Gdansk. Several containers have been already washed ashore, some damaged, with goods scattered along coastline. MAERSK released a statement confirming that containers were lost due to rough weather.

Bulk carrier suffered total failure of main engine transmission after departing Port de Montreal,  0.52NM SSE of Poulier de la Longue Pointe, Canada. She proceeded to anchorage off Pointe-aux-Trembles to assess issue.
Ferry reported damages to port main engine en route to Tilos, Greece. She returned to Rhodes for inspection. No inj0uries or pollution reported.

The canal pilot reported vessel was too deep in water in Great Northern Lock of Kiel Canal in Brunsbuttel, Germany, due to a defect in ballast water system. The vessel was banned from sailing until repairs were carried out.

Fishing vessel broke loose in storm Pia at North Sea Yards in port of Hanstholm Harbor, Denmark. Lifeboat C.B. Claudi along with 20 men fought to secure her. Tug Bestla was also called to assist. Vessel sailed o 27 December.

A crew member fell ill on board the vessel while en route from Istanbul to Ghent. When his condition deteriorated, it was decided that he was going to be medevaced by a H160 helicopter from the Lanvéoc base. The man was taken to the hospital Cavale Blanche in Brest.

Cruise ship suffered a blackout in North sea, while en route from Floro Norway to Tilbury UK. Reports say a huge wave flooded the bridge and disabled navigational equipment. ESVAGT safety and supply tugs assisted.

Car carrier was caught in storm Zoltan while berthed at car terminal along Ems river, outside inner port in Emden. She broke off her moorings and started drifting in the river. Tugs were quickly deployed to assist and avoided vessel being involved in a serious accident. She was berthed in new inner harbor safely.

A fire erupted on board vessel in Yangtze river, near Sutong Bridge, Shanhai, en route from Changzhou to Incheon Korea. All crew were evacuated as vessel developed heavy starboard list and stern tilt and fire spread to cargo tanks area. SAR is underway, a number of tugs and auxiliary vessels are nearby.

A group of protesters in kayaks, aiming to interrupt shipments heading to Israel, attempted to block lock the path of the vessel in the Yarra River, while en route from Sydney, New South Wales to Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. She was able to dock after one hour and port operations resumed.
Vehicles carrier collided with container ship MARGARET RIVER BRIDGE at the entrance of the Tokyo Bay. No reports on damages. The next day the BANGKOK HIGHWAY was en route from Yokohama to Omaezaki.
Vessel collided with vehicles carrier BANGKOK HIGHWAY at the entrance of the Tokyo Bay, en route from Hakata to Tokyo. No reports on damages.
