Six individuals boarded a ship in Sao Tome & Principe EEZ, stealing supplies, equipment, and personal belongings, and damaging bridge equipment.
Ferry broke loose from berth in the Port of Terschelling, Netherlands due to strong winds but was quickly taken under control and moored again.
Ferry experienced engine failure and started drifting in the South Pacific Ocean, near Fiji. Landing craft Waimana towed the ferry to the port of Savusavu.
Vessel collided with inland tanker TN-709 in river Don below Rostov-on-Don, while en route from Rostov to Mersin, Turkey. She suffered bow damages with hole above waterline. No reports of leaks.
Tug suffered water ingress in  the Gulf of Mexico. She safely berthed in the Intracoastal City Port and remained there as of 21 December.
Vessel's cargo of pellets caught fire  while berthed at Soderhamn, Sweden, Gulf of Bothnia. The smoldering cargo was offloaded on pier and fire extinguished.
Container ship ran aground near Walsoorden, Netherlands. She was refloated the same day, then berthed for inspection at MSC PSA European Terminal, 2.2 NM from Antwerpen, Belgium..
Vessel had technical failure in navigation system along with alarm units at Eregli, Turkey. Repairs were done by crew and sailed from Eregli on 20 December.

Reports of vessel sinking or already sank in Bali sea NE of Bali island, Indonesia, while en route from Tuban port, northern Java to Maumere, Flores island. Rescue vessel attended. 13 crew members climbed into life raft and 8 are missing. Cause of sinking not known.

Cargo ship had enfine failure off Kavkaz, Kerch Strait. On 9 January she arrived at Cemre Shipyard where repairs were being carried out by shore-based technical teams. As of 8 February she was stationary at Yalova, Marmara Sea, Turkey.
Vessel suffered engine failure due to diesel leakage in engine room and started drifting close to the shore of Sandnessjoen, Norway. Coast Guard vessel KV Heimdal towed her to Sandnessjoen.
Reports vessel suffered engine failure, lost power and drifted off Istanbul strait, Turkey. Coastal Safety tug Kurtarma 2 and a fast rescue boat secured her to Istanbul anchorage.
Tanker suffered total propulsion loss in St Lawrence River off Sorel, 0.67nm W NW of Pointe aux Pins, QC, Canada. She sailed to anchorage in Port de Montreal for assessment.
A fire broke out in galley and cabin area, in Catania, Italy. Three crew members were intoxicated by smoke, one of whom was taken to hospital. An investigation was launched.

An explosion occured on board while en route from Kalecik to Famagusta, Cyprus. Two crew members were injured and were taken to state hospital. Vessel anchored at Famagusta anchorage. No reports on the extent of damages and cause of explosion.
A fire broke out due to a shortcircuit in cabling of vessel, on Middenhavendam in Breskens, Netherlands. The fire was brought under control promptly.

The Houthis said on the Telegram channel that attacks had been launched against the Swan Atlantic and the 19,224-teu boxship MSC Clara (built 2015). The statement said the vessels were targeted by two aircraft after “their crews refused to respond to the calls of the Yemeni naval forces.”

Norwegian owner Inventor Chemical Tankers said the vessel was hit by an unidentified object and that none of its crew had been injured. Oystein Elgan, its chief executive, told Reuters the ship’s water tank had been damaged in the attack but all systems were operating normally. Danish operator Uni-Tankers said in a statement the crew had brought a small fire under control after a hit to its port side. The ship is carrying vegetable oils. Inventor Chemical Tankers has no ties to Israel, Elgan said. The ship had left Yangbu Industrial Port in Saudi Arabia on 15 December and was bound for Port Reunion. The Houthis said on the Telegram channel that attacks had been launched against the Swan Atlantic and the 19,224-teu boxship MSC Clara (built 2015).

Approximately 300 kgs of cocaine were found on board vessel in Foynes, County Limerick, Ireland, by a joint Customs and Guards Security officers team. The vessel had arrived from Brazil via Canada and was detained together with 6 crew members, of which 4 were released pending further investigations. As of 1 Januray, the bulk carrier was still at Foynes.

Bulk carrier ran aground as she was entering berth at  Krishnapatnam, eastern India. She was supposed to be refloated by dredgers with high tide on 26 December. As of 7 January vessel was still anchored off Krishnapatnam port.
Container ship was NUC due to main engine injector failure, in English Channel, UK. Vessel's main engineer carried out repairs and vessel continued voyage after about two hours.
FREDO was struck by a vessel after a man untied the mooring line and let her float in Hunte, in Oldenburg, Germany. Damage was in the lower 5 figure range.

General cargo ship sank in South China Sea, 35 nm north of Da Nang, Vietnam, while en route from Hai Phong to Vung Tau. SAR was underway working to rescue crew. Reports two of them went missing. No reports on the cause of sinking.
Ferry allided with the quay on arrival in Malmo, Sweden. She suffered minor damages and sailed the same day to Travemunde.

UPDATE: 22-Dec-2023 Vessel was reported to have leaked around 20 tons of diesel fuel, which covered 300 metres of the shorelike of Jibei Island. Oil containment booms could not be deployed due to rough seas and high winds. The Ocean Conservation Administration, along with the Taiwan Coast Guard are working to contain the spill. Cargo vessel ran aground north of the Baisha Township, near Jibei after suffering power loss due to mechanical fault. She was en route from Taichung to Kaohsiung and lost power soon after leaving the port. All crew members were rescued by a National Airborne Service Corps helicopter after the captain gave the order to abandon ship.
Ferry ran aground in the Port of Tomakomai, Japan. Vessel refloated by own means the same day and was berthed. No reports of damages. She sailed from Tomakomai the same day.
Bulk carrier had issues with the emergency generator at Vancouver Wharves Terminal in Vancouver, BC, Canada. Repairs were carried our and sailed on 22 December.

Cruise ship was caught in bad weather and had to sail to Boston, Massachusetts, while en route from New York to Florida and the Bahamas.  Heavy rain and strong winds were forecast in Florida and the Bahamas so vessel was to be docked in Boston until 19 December before heading to Portland, Maine and then Saint John, Newfoundland, then returning to New York.
Vessel suffered mechanical failure as she was about to enter Canakkale strait at Kumkale point. She shifted to South of Bozcaada Island anchorage for repairs by crew.
Vessel experienced mechanical failure during Canakkale Strait passage, en route from Larymna, Greece to Tuzla, Turkey. She was moored at Karanlik liman anchorage for repairs.
Vessel suffered failure of auxiliary engines, pipes and pertinent alarms at Bartin, Turkey.. Departure permission was cancelled. She sailed from Bartin on 26 December.

SIBEL J suffered pollution prevention system failure together with alarm units and pertinent connections at Eregli, Turkey. Departure was cancelled and repairs were carried out by the crew. She sailed from Eregli anchorage on 18 December.
Vessel had technical failure during Istanbul Strait passage and dropped anchor at Buyukdere anchorage. Crew carried out repairs and sailed the next day.
Vessel had a crack between HFO tank and ballast tank in Birkenhead, River Mersey, UK. Oil Spill Responder AMBIPAR attended on site along with workboat Forth Hunter. Fence booms were deployed.
Vessel had propulsion issues due to loss of power, about 2.5nm from Coarsewall Lighthouse, Scotland. Repairs were carried out and continued voyage.
Tanker experienced mechanical failure at Novorossiysk, Russia . Departure permission was temporarily cancelled until repairs. Vessel was stationary at Novorossiysk as of 19 December.
A missile targeted the vessel while transiting the Bab El Mandeb strait. Reports that she was on fire and had to turn around. Vessels in the area were advised to be cautious.

Vessel requested medical assistance while in Bay of Biscay, en route from San Ciprian, Spain to Norway. A French rescue helicopter brought a medical team on board but they found the ship captain was already dead. Vessel called at Brest to disembark body, undergo formalities and probably, wait for a new Captain. NO reports on the cause of death.
Reports vessel was NUC in the North Sea and a navigational warning was issued by the Netherlands Coast Guard. As of 18 December vessel was berthed at Terminal Autoeuropa in Setubal, Portugal.
Bulk carrier experienced engine failure shortly after departing Anch. No.3 in Departure Bay, Newcastle Island, BC ,Canada. She anchored again for repairs and sailed on 21 December.
Container ship was hit portside by projectile launched by the Yemen controlled Houthi rebels. A fire erupted on board and one container fell overboard. No reports of injuries.
Vessel experienced technical failure during Canakkale Strait passage and dropped anchor at Karanlik Liman anchorage. Repairs were carried out by crew.
Container ship suffered total loss of propulsion power, about 22.70 Nm SW of Race Point, in the Gulf of Maine, Nova Scotia. Crew repaired the main engine while adrift and resumed voyage.

UPDATE: 15-Mar-2024 The Indian Navy intercepted the vessel around 1400 nautical miles off the Indian coast and deployed  its P-81 maritime patrol aircraft, frontline warships INS Kolkata and INS Subhadra, and high-altitude long endurance (HALE) unmanned aerial vehicles. The pirated shot down on of the drones and as a response the Indian Navy disabled the vessel's steering system, forcing her to stop. The entire operation lasted for about 40 hours. All pirated surrendered and the 17 crew members were successfully rescued. Bulk carrier was hijacked and 17 crew kidnapped, while en route from Singapore to Turkey. She was followed by Spanish and Indian Navy vessels as she was steered into Puntland waters, in the Gulf of Aden, northeast Somalia. As of 17 December vessel was cruising in figure eight loops in Puntland waters, west from Horn of Africa.

The yacht allided with bridge next to Virgin Voyages terminal in Miami, US, after being swept away by strong currents created by the departure of a cruise ship that was being helped by several tug boats.

A crew member suffered injuried to his left hand while working in the engine room. He was in need of immediat medical attention. The Kochin Port Authority deployed a tug to transfer the patient to shore.
Ferry experienced port radar failure which restricted operations between Oban, Coll and Tiree, UK. Repairs were carried out and sailings were to resume on 19 December.

Reports two missiles launched from territory controlled by Yemen’s Houthi rebels targeted and missed the tanker, while sailing north towards the Suez Canal, near the strategic Bab el-Mandeb Strait, Red Sea. There are no reports of damages to the vessel and no injuries.

Cargo vessel lost about 5% of her cargo due to rough weather, about 1.6nm east of the Blyth pier, north-east England, while en route from Aberdeen to Dover. Later in the afternoon she berthed at Sunderland to secure shifted cargo.

A fire erupted in the vessel's hull, probably due to leakage in fuel oil hose, in Teluk Meranti Waters, Indonesia. Tug Marina Vista attended and evacuated 10 crew members. One other crew member could not be found.
Ferry suffered starboard main engine failure while en route Lochboisdale to Mallaig, UK. Her departure from Lochboisdale to Oban was delayed as replacement parts were needed.

Bulk carrier collided with fishing vessel SHENG FENG NO.12, 77nm off Candon town, Philippines. Fishing vessel suffered water ingress due to bow damage and needed portable pumps to draw out seawater. No reports of damages or injuries on the JAWAD.
A crew member was injured after falling on board the ship in Dirk Metselaarhaven (Achtersluispolder) in Zaandam, Netherlands. He was rescued and promptly transferred to a hospital.

Cruise ship broke off her moorings in high winds at Princess Wharf, Waitemata Harbour, Auckland. 10 commuter ferries were cancelled and others were bobbing in harbour, unable to dock. Vessel departed from the harbour the next day.
Vessel was struck by self-discharging bulk carrier MICHIPICOTEN at Rogers City, USA. She didn't suffer any serious damages and arrived in the Port of Superior on 16 December.
Vessel allided with self-discharging bulk carrier KAYE E. BARKER and a wharf while leaving Rogers City, USA. Crew assessed damages and sailed to Sarnia, Ontario to carry out temporary repair works.

Reports vessel ran aground in Órmos Vistonías, Greece. She was refloated with the help pf a tugboat and moored at Porto Logo the next day. The local port authority detained her until repairs were carried out on 13 December.
Ferry LOCH RIDDON suffered generator issue and sailings between Oban and Lismore, UK had to be canceled. Investigation is  ongoing in Oban.
SIRIMAU lost control and collided with pier in Ambon, Indonesia. There were damages to vessel's bulbous bow, pier, docks and boulders. Vessel suffered water ingress.

Container ship experienced propulsion failure and started drifting in Celtic sea 35 nm west of Ushant, while en route from Southampton to Montoir port, France, Bay of Biscay. Tug ABEILLE BOURBON towed vessel to Brest.

UPDATE: 17-Dec-2023 A major fire erupted on board and disabled vessel. US Navy ship evacuated all crew. The Strinda was hit by a missile about 15 nautical miles (28 km) west of Mokha in Yemen on Monday. A fire broke out on board but it was extinguished by the Indian crew, who remained unharmed. The tanker was underway northbound in the southern Red Sea at the time at 12 knots, with AIS transmissions still on.

Bulk carrier had engine trouble while anchored 17 miles off Scaterie Island, Cape Breton, Canada. Repairs were carried out by the crew and a tug was onsite to provide assistance.  o reports of pollution. Vessel sailed on 16 December.
Fishing vessel ran aground 24.5NM SW of Kos Island, Greece. She was refloted by own means and was escorted to Kalymnos by a Coast Guard vessel.
Tanker suffered engine failure 20nm SE of Lillesand in Skagerrak, Denmark. Patrol vessel Sortland towed vessel into Kristiansund. Vessel sailed the next day, bound for Skagen.
Rhodes Port Authority, Greece reported that vessel allided with pier while mooring at Rhodes. There were damages to port bow and Schengen control gate. Sailing was banned until repairs.
Vessel was NUC and started drifting due to main engine failure in North Sea. Crew carried out repairs and continued voyage the same day.
Tug suffered main engine sea water cooling system failure in Quebec, Canada. She was towed to Sept-Iles by tug Ocean Raymond Lemay for repairs.
Ferry experienced mechanical failure and sailings between Colintraive and Rhubodach, UK were suspended. Inspection and repairs were carried out in Colintraive.
Ferry suffered generator fault in Berneray, UK and required further investigations. Sailings from Berneray and Leverburgh were disrupted.
Bulk carrier ran aground while entering Tuticorin, India. She was refloated with the help of tugs and entered port with high tide. Berthed in Dakhsin Bharat Gateway.
Reports vessel had engine issues due to rough weather and lost power on her service from Izuhara to Ashibe, Japan. Coast Guard assisted with patrol boats and an aircraft.

UPDATE: 14-Dec-2023 Vessel has been refloated and is in the process of mooring to crude oil tanker VALENTE, another possible member of the so-called dark fleet. Shadow-Fleet Oil Tanker Grounds Near Singapore. A shadow-fleet oil tanker, the Liberty, has run aground in Indonesian waters near to Singapore, carrying around 1m bbl of Venezuelan oil, according to Bloomberg. The grounding is another incident near Singapore involving a tanker from the dark-fleet – tankers that help move sanctioned barrels across the globe. • The Liberty also suffered a collision earlier in the year in the Black Sea, according to data from the Global Integrated Shipping Information System database. 02-May-2003: In collision with bulk Junior M. in the Black Sea in 43 17.8 N 34 24 E 02 May 2003. Damage at port side of forward peak. Sailed 03 May for Constantza for repairs, arrived 07 May. Still under repair 19 May. ETC 04 Jun.
Reports vessel ran aground in Yangtze river in front of Changxing island, Shainghai, between Buoys 45 and 47, en route from Jingtang Bohai sea. At least two tugs were deployed to assist.

Three crew members were reported to be critiacally ill in South China Sea, off Bolinao, northwest Luzon, while en route from USA to Singapore. The ship interrupted voyage and headed to Manila for medical assistance. Ship's master later reported that the three men have died. Vessel arrived at Manila next evening, where bodies were transferred to port. No reports on the cause of death.
Container ship was NUC due to a mechanical fault NW of Paros Island, Greece. She was towed by two tugs to Bay of Varis, off SE coast of Syros Island. Repairs were done and sailed on 19 December.

Vessel had technical failure, sheltered and dropped anchor at Datca anchorage, Turkey, while en route from Kiliia, Ukraine to Abu Kir, Egypt. Repairs were done by crew. Vessel was still at anchorage as of 11 December.
Ferry had to be sidelined at Anacortes after several mechanical issues. She reumed her service from Anacortes to San Juan Islands on 14 January.
Vessel was nuc due to main engine cylinder over heating, 39 NM SSE Lizard, Cornwall, UK. Tug ALP Striker towed her to Bayonne, France for repairs.
Vessel had technical failure during Istanbul Strait passage and dropped anchor at Buyukdere anchorage. Crew carried out repairs,
A crew member fell ill 110nm southwest of Paphos, Cyprus, while en route from Cartagena, Spain to Hereke, Turkey. He was medevaced by helicopter and transferred to the Paphos general hospital.
Ferry experienced steering issues which needed to be investigated in Kennacraig. Sailings were cancelled until repairs.
Tanker had propulsion malfunction which caused her breaking off mooring ropes and damaging nearby boat at Vohemar, Madagascar. No reports of injuries or pollution.
The yacht collided with dock gate in hall dock at Lurssen Aumund in Bremen, Germany where she is under construction. She suffered bow damage and one worked suffered a minor injury.
Vessel collided with dock due to mechanical issue and was taken out of service at Vashon Island, US. Engineers attended for repairs.
Vessel suffered mechanical failure, sheltered and dropped anchor at Datca anchorage, Turkey. Crew carried out repairs and sailed from anchorage on 9 December.
Technician attended on board the vessel to fix an issue with the elevator. Sailings between Oban and Craignure were suspended.

UPDATE: Temporary repairs were scheduled for 11 December, as vessel had a scrape/gash along the side of the hull. She was anchored off Port Said, Egypt. Container ship suffered mechanical failure due to rudder issues in eastern lane of Suez Canal in front of Ismailia, en route from Singapore to Netherlands and then ran into embankment, hitting moored pontoon. She was refloated approximately 3 hours later and resumed transit. Traffic was partially blocked for a few hours.
Bulk carrier suffered engine failure, about 5.00 NM SW of Point Atkinson in the Strait of Georgia, Canada. She proceeded to Vancouver anchorage and sailed on 8 December.
A fire erupted in cargo hold at Tilbury Docks, UK, while loading metal scrap. Five fire teams responded and contained the fire. The scrap was offloaded to be able to get to the  smoldering hotspots.

200 kgs of cocaine were seized by Costa Rica’s Drug Control Police at the Gaston Kogan dock in Moin, Limon. The cocaine had been concealed in the engine room. Vessel was en route from Colombia to Antwerp, Belgium. No arrests were made, vessel resumed voyage on 8 December.

Reports vessel was involved in a hit and run accident in South China Sea, 33 nm off western coast of Mindoro, Philippines. She apparently struck fishing vessel RUEL J and sailed away without offering any help to the distressed fishermen. An investigation is on. All 5 crew of the fishing boat were rescued.

Container ship was attacked by Houthi Militia in the Red Sea and suffered damages to her hull. On 24 December she arrived at Yalova, Marmara Sea, Turkey and berthed at the Sefinae Shipyard for repairs.

Tug was raided by Thailand Police at Bang Pakong port, near Bangkok, Thailand. They seized more than two tons of crystal methamphetamine and have arrested 13 Thai nationals, suspected to be part of an international smuggling ring.

Tanker suffered engine failure and started drifting 61nm off the coast of Ouessant (Ushant), western France, while en route from Antwerp to Ravenna. Crew carried out repairs and vessel resumed voyage the same day.
Tanker ran aground in Amazon river some 30 nm downstream from Manaus, en route from Manaus to Itacoatiara, Brazil. Reports say she hit rocks and developed portside list. A tug was deployed to assist.
Bulk carrier suffered engine failure off Ostend, Belgium and moored at Wandelaar Anchorage. Vessel was towed by tugs and moored at Vrasen Dock in port of destination on 9 December.
Container ship suffered engine failure in the St. Lawrence River off Contrecoeur, Canada. She anchored off Lanoraie, Quebec, crew assessed issue and sailed from anchorage on 4 December.

Reportedly, the vessel was attacked by a drone or missile, in the Red Sea. She suffered minor damages and there were no casualties. Pentagon said it was aware of attacks on an American warship and commercial vessels in the Red Sea.
Vessel suffered total failure of automated propulsion control system in Boundary Pass, BC, Canada. Crew switched to manual propulsion control and sailed to destination for complete assessment.
Reports vessel was in contact with a projectile in Southern Sea, but there was no significant damage. USS Carney responded and shot down a UAV on her way to help the bulk carrier.

SAR vessel was detained by the Italian authorities in Crotone. They accused SOS Humanity of ignoring Lybian Coast Guard instructions to leave the area during the rescue operation of 46 people who were in the water. SOS Humanity denied the allegations and declared will take legal action in order to free the vessel.
An electrical fire erupted in one of vessel's bridge power supplies in Gulf of St. Lawrence, 41.80NM NE Pointe de l'Est, QC, Canada. Fire was extinguished by crew and resumed voyage.

Oil tanker suffered engine fault during transit of Fehmarn Belt. Vessel emitted thick black smoke several times and had to sail at reduced speed of 10 knots. She sailed from Port Said Roads Anchorage, Egypt on 18 December.

Fours semi-trailers were lost overboard in Ligurian sea, between Corsica and Italian coast, near Ligurian Sea Cetacean Sanctuary, known as Pelagos Sanctuary, while en route from Malta via Catania, to Genoa. So far there were no reports of pollution although one of the trailers is loaded with sulfuric acid. An investigation is on.
Vessel was NUC due to unconfirmed issue with water cooling of engine, resulting in overheating in the English Channel, UK. Crew fitted a new cylinder engine cover and sailed on 3 December.

The icebreaker experienced engine failure and had to drop anchor off coast of Lorient near island of Groix, France. The crew members asked to be evacuated and complained about their working environment and the poor condition of the vessel.
Ferry had technical error while en route from Jektvik to Kilboghamn, Norway. Sailings were cancelled until further notice. She remained in Kilboghamn for repairs.
yacht suffered technical fault, lost control of engines and ran aground in Marina Harbour, Dubai. There were no damages reported.
Fish carrier developed a port side list of 45 degrees while berthed at the Solstrand Shipyard in Tomrefjord, Norway. She was stabilised by counter-filling the opposite tank.

A crew member fell overboard in River Elbe near Otterndorf. The Cuxhaven traffic centre of the Waterways and Shipping Administration had raised the alert, sparking an SAR operation. He was swiftly found by Motor hopper Pieter Caland which offered him medical care on board. After his body temperature returned to normal he was transferred in a lifeboat to a hospital in Cuxhaven.

Motor hopper rescued a crew member of bulk carrier Athina L, after he fell overboard in River Elbe near Otterndorf, between marker buoys 44 and 46. He received medical care on board and after his body temperature returned to normal, he was transferred in a lifeboat to a hospital in Cuxhaven.

UPDATE: On 14 January the third engineer of the vessel attempted suicide after having been isolated and unable to make contact with family. Indian authorities have confiscated crew's mobile phones and computers. The engineer was rescued and taken to Paradip Port Authority Hospital. 20 kgs of cocaine have been seized from the vessel at Paradip Port, India. At least 10 persons were under investigation, including 3 crew members 6 crane operators and a managerial level employee of a stevedoring agency. Divers were called in to search for more drugs that may have been hidden  in the keel or elsewhere in the hull. The ship had arrived from Gresik, Indonesia and was supposed to sail to Denmark.
Vessel ran aground  in the Astrakhan region near the village of Solenoye Zaymishche. Traffic in the area was not affected. No reports of pollution.

Vessel suffered mechanical failure at Novorossiysk, Black Sea, Russia, en route from Samsun. Departure permission was cancelled until repairs and inspection by state surveyors. As of 9 December she was still at the port.

A fire erupted in engine room on Rhine, at river 541300 km near Lorch, Germany. Ship CO2 extinguished fire and the fire brigade completed extinguishing process. No injuries reported. Vessel was towed 800m to Rudesheim and was banned from sailing.
FRI SEA' portside wheelhouse collided with bulwark on bow of fully cellular containership ELBWAVE in Kiel Canal at 55km near Rusterbergen,Germany. Wheelhouse was severely deformed.
Bulwark on bow of vessel collided with portside lookout wheelhouse of general cargo with container capacity FRI SEA in Kiel Canal, 55km near Rusterbergen, Germany. Bow was slightly dented.
Port Authority of Mytilene was informed that the vessel suffered mechanical failure. Greek Coast Guard attended. Repairs were ongoing.
Vessel suffered main engine control system failure while being assisted by shipyard tugs for sea trials, in Burrard Inlet, BC, Canada. She was towed to Vancouver shipyard.
Cargo ship was stuck in ice in River Neva, St. Petersburg, Russia. Tug Nevskaya Zastava  assisted and on 2 December she reached ice-free water and continued voyage under own power.
Ferry had issue with the radar on board and affected her berthing operation. The service between Oban and Lochboisdale was affected and operated under an amended timetable until 1 December.
Reports vessel experienced engine failure in English Channel some 55 nm SE of Falmouth UK, en route from Rafnes, Norway to Gibraltar. She was towed Falmouth for repairs.

Container ship lost portside anchor at Thessaloniki anchorage, Greece, while preparing to enter into port. She was berthed at pier no 6. Sailed from anchorage on 30 November after the anchor was lifted.

3 crew members were in need of immediate medical attention, 8nm northwest of Kythira, en route from Kalamata to Civitavecchia. They were picked up by a lifeboat which took them to the port of Kalamata and then they were taken to the General Hospital of Messina by ambulance.

Vessel suffered another engine failure, this time during Canakkale strait passage. She dropped anchor at Burhanli point in the strait. Tugs Kurtarma 4, Kurtarma 14, fast rescue boat and duty pilot towed her to Karnalik Liman anchorage.

Crew and vessel were detained after a Senegalese Navy patrol boat intercepted them 80nm off the Senegal coast. Vessel was taken to Dakar Naval Base where authorities have found three tons of cocaine. An investigation is on.

Vessel ran aground during dredging and suffered hull damage and water ingress in pump room, off island of Usedom in Steintrendel area. Pump room was sealed off and vessel sailed to Lubmin, Germany under own power. No injuries reported.

UPDATE: Tugs were able to refloat vessel with high tide and improved weather. Reportedly, she was towed to Tuzla for repairs. Tanker, caught in severe weather, dragged anchor at Ahirkapi anchorage and drifted onto embankment at Zeytinburnu, Istanbul, Marmara Sea. Vessel suffered hull breach with water ingress in engine room. It is believed she might rest on bottom, as partially above waterline.

Vessel experienced water ingress while en route from Vung Tau to Nghi Son, northern Vietnam. It was decided that she be grounded at Thang Binh district waters in order to avoid sinking. All crew were safely evacuated.
Ferry had engine failure off Haydarpasa, Turkey. Tug Kurtarma-12 towed to Yenikapi anchorage. Repairs were carried out by crew. and sailed from Yenikapi anchorage the same day.
Vessel dragged anchor, drifted and collided with bulk carrier Aqua Regia at Iskenderun anchorage, Turkey. Loading operations  were completed and saild from Sariseki on 2 December.
Vessel broke off her moorings at Inebolu port, Turkey, Black sea, and drifted ashore in Filli Kosk area. All crew were safely rescued.

Bulk carrier MATROS SHEVCHENKO was caught in a storm while leaving port Kavkaz, in Kerch Strait. She los control and contacted anchored bulk carrier MATROS POZYNICH. Both vessels then drifted onto bulk carrier KAVKAZ V which was about to leave anchorage as well. Reportedly, the three ship have suffered only minor damages.

General cargo with container capacity Coral C dragged anchor, drifted and collided with bulk carrier Aqua Regia at Iskenderun anchorage, Turkey. Aqua Regia berthed in Sariseki port for cargo operations.
FR PEARL was caught in strong winds and dragged anchor at Hopa, Turkey, Black sea coast. All crew were evacuated safely.

Vessel came perpendicular to fairway, leaving new northern lock of Kiel Canal in Brunsbuttel, Germany and slipped along pilings of tails. She stopped without major damage and left Brunsbuttel escorted by tugs.

Bulk carrier ran aground in Detroit river between Detroit downtown and Belle island, while leaving the anchorage, en route from Sault Ste Marie to Gibraltar. A tug was deployed to assist. No reports on damages or leaks.

Bulk carrier MATROS SHEVCHENKO was caught in a storm while leaving port Kavkaz, in Kerch Strait. She los control and contacted anchored bulk carrier MATROS POZYNICH. Both vessels then drifted onto bulk carrier KAVKAZ V which was about to leave anchorage as well. Reportedly, the three ship have suffered only minor damages.

Bulk carrier was caught in a storm while leaving port Kavkaz, in Kerch Strait. She los control and contacted anchored bulk carrier MATROS POZYNICH. Both vessels then drifted onto bulk carrier KAVKAZ V which was about to leave anchorage as well. Reportedly, the three ship have suffered only minor damages.

A U.S. Navy warship, USS Mason, responded to a distress call from the commercial tanker in the Gulf of Aden, Seized by armed individuals. Five armed individuals tried to escape but were chased by the warship. The incident follows a series of Middle Eastern attacks since the war broke out.

Four crew members were reported missing in the Mississippi River, after they didn't turn up for a standard safety drill. A 48 hours search brought no results and it was called off as it was suspected that the men left the ship voluntarily, intending to stay in the US illegally.
Vessel suffered mechanical ussues and was  removed from Brekstad-Valset route, Norway by operator Fjord1. She was sidelined in Brekstad for repairsand sailed the same day.

UPDATE: Only one body was recovered from the waters near Lesbos. As of 1 December, the Greek Coastguard has ended the search for the other 12 missing crew members. Reports vessel sank off southwest coast of Lesbos island, Greece, Aegean sea, en route from Egypt to Istanbul, after being disabled in extreme weather. The most probable cause for sinking would be cargo shift. Of the 14 crew members on board only one was rescued while the others are missing. SAR was underway with helicopters and nearby freighters seaching for them.

UPDATE: Crew couldn't carry out repairs so vessel was granted a single voyage permit after tug expenses were paid. She left Constanta on 10 December and arrived to Yalova shipyard area south of Istanbul on 12 December. Cargo ship was caught in extreme winds and dragged anchor in the Black Sea near Constanta, Romania. She drifted to the inner breakwater and partially grounded. A tug and technical team assisted and towed vessel to pier. No reports of injuries or pollution. Damages were being assessed.
Ferry ran aground on the coast of Rometta, in front of Via Caterina Carbone. She ws being towed by tug TEDY when the tow rope broke and started drifting. Vessel was refloted on 28 November.
Bulk carrier was beached at Vityazevo, Anapa area, Russia, Black sea, after being caught in a storm. No reports on SAR.
Tanker suffered water ingress in bow thruster engine room on Mittelland Canal near Hanover, Germany. Firefighters attended and used 3 pumps to cope with flooding.
Vessel had water ingress on Mittelland Canal in area of Anderten lock near Hanover, Germany. 54 emergency services and 16 vehicles attended.

Vessel allided with wharf while departing from Port of Nagoya, Japan. A survey by port administrator was scheduled for 27 November to confirm condition of wharf. The ship only suffered some scratches.

The Master and the second Master of vessel were arrested by the Port Authority of Thessaloniki, Greece for disrupting the safety of water transportation by exceeding the loading line. She was listed as "underway" on 30 November.

Ferry collided with ferry SUPERFAST II and product tanker AEGEAN TIFFANY, during berthing manoeuvres in Patras, Greece. She suffered minor damages and was berthed at Hellenic Shipyard in Elevsis on 29 November.

Ferry HELLENIC SPIRIT collided with ferry SUPERFAST II and product tanker AEGEAN TIFFANY, during berthing manoeuvres in Patras, Greece. No reports of injuries or pollution. AEGEAN TIFFANY sailed from port on 27 November.

Ferry HELLENIC SPIRIT collided with ferry SUPERFAST II and product tanker AEGEAN TIFFANY, during berthing manoeuvres in Patras, Greece. No injuries or pollution reported. SUPERFAST II sailed from port on 26 November.

Vessel collided with tugs deckhouse after breaking of tow line, while towing fully cellular containership TENO, in Hamburg, Germany. Bridge window was destroyed and the captain suffered a serious eye injury.
Vessel's saloon was flooded due to clogged drains in Seivika, Norway. A pump truck was installed and ferry was taken our of her Seivika - Tommervag service.

A COVID-19 outbreak was reported on board the vessel while in Montreal. This led to the cancelation of the tour of Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence Seaway, Canada and vessel was expeced to return to Halifax on 26 November.

Ferry encountered problems with port side anchor when about to depart from Kyllini Port, bound for Poros in Kefallinia. All passengers and vehicles were taken over by ferry Andreas Kalvos, which took them to destination.
Vessel had technical failure, sheltered and dropped anchor at Hisaronu anchorage, Turkey. Repairs were carried out by crew and sailed on 30 November.

ANASTASIA reported to Leros Port Authority that she had main engine troubles SW of Patmos Island, Greece. Coast Guard vessel accompanied her to Leros where she dropped anchor. Sailing banned until repairs.
A fire broke out in a dry dock during welding works on a ventilation duct at Westcon Shipyard in centre of Floro, Norway. Fire was extinguished promptly with no casualties.
A fire erupted on board the vessel after she sailed from Palermo, en route to Genoa, Italy. Crew extinguished fire. Vessel was escorted to Naples by ferry SPLENDID. No injuries reported.
Ferry touched bottom at Hojstene, Denmark, while en route from Svendborg to Aeroskobing. She was berted at Aeroskobing for inspection. No pollition reported. Resumed service the same day.
Vessel ran aground in St. Lawrence river, upstream from Portneuf, en route from Gibraltar to Montreal. Reports of water ingress in engine room. Several tugs were assisting to refloat.
Vessel suffered another main engine failure in Chenal Laurentien, 15.70 NM ENE Rochers aux Oiseaux, Quebec, Canada. Vessel stopped and crew carried out repairs while adrift before resuming voyage.
Reports vessel sustained some damages after being attacked by an Iranian drone in the Arabian Sea. Reportedly, the attack happened due to vessel being owned by an Israeli company.
Ferry had technical issues while en route from Lekneset to Saebo, Norway. She was sideline in Saebo for repairs and passenger boat Horundfjord was inserted as replacement.
Tug ran aground on sandbank while trying to tow a fishing vessel from Zandvoort, Netherlands. This was caused by tow rope getting stuck into the propeller. Tug OCEAAN towed to Rotterdam.
Vessel got stuck in sea due to lack of adequate drafts. Two tugboats were deployed to assist with re-boarding. She left for Hazira the same day.
Ferry had technical issue and was withdrawn from service between Mallaig and Armadale, UK. Technicians investigatedissue at berth in Mallaig.
The ship's captain suffered a heart attack at at Taranto anchorage, Italy. A patrol boat transferred him to port where he received medical treatment and was under stable condition.
Bulk carrier experienced mechanical failure at Kumkale point in Canakkale strait, Turkey. She dropped anchor at Karanlik liman anchorage under own power and resumed voyage the same day.
Ferry suffered damages to lift. Engineers carried out repairs at the quay in Rothesay. Sailings were cancelled until further notice.

Ashdod Port Authority advised vessels in the area to keep a 1nm distance from the vessel due to restricted ability to manoeuvre. She was to be towed by tug EDT Andromeda to dry dock at Chalkis, Greece.
Ferry touched bottom  off Stigsnaes, Denmark due to very low water levels. No reports of pollution. Vessel continued service between Omo and Stigsnaes.
Ferry was taken out of service for the rest of the day in Hodnanes-Jektevik-Nordhuglo, Norway, due to a power outage. She was sidelined in Sunde for repairs.
Sailing between Tallinn, Estonia and Stockholm, Sweden was suspended due to storm damage. Repairs were carried out and ferry sailed on 25 November.

Bulk carrier experienced main engine’s fuel system fault in the Haro Strait, British Columbia, Canada. She moved to an anchorage in the vicinity of the Constance Bank and after crew assessed issue, she berthed in Vancouver. As of 28 November she was en route from Vancouver to Hong Kong.
Vessel allided with the stern of berthed bulk carrier FEDERAL MONTREAL, as she arrived in Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, Canada. Crew assessed damages, no pollution reported.

Reports vessel experienced engine failure in Outer Weser while navigating from Bremerhaven to Hamburg and had to drop anchor in fairway between buoys 43 and 44,  in front of Wremer Loch. Four tugs were deployed to assist and vessel resumed sailing under own power after about 11 hours.
Vessel was struck by self discharging bulk carrier Algoma Mariner while berthed at Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, Canada. No reports of pollution.
YAROPOLK suffered mechanical failure during Istanbul Strait passage and dropped anchor at Buyukdere anchorage, Turkey. Repairs were carried out and she sailed on 24 November.

Vessel was caught by strong currents on Danube river and touched bottom. She interrupted voyage and returned to Linz. She had damages in bow region, at hull and at railings. Sailings cancelled until repairs are done.

Car carrier ran aground in shallows while entering Hanko port, Finland, in rough weather conditions. Vessel was refloated almost two hours later. She anchored in Gulf of Finland awaiting to try and enter Hanko again. No damages reported

Cargo ship suffered engine failure, en route from Reni to Egypt. She was taken to Tulcea for repairs. On 22 January the vessel was towed by tug SEA VANQUISH as repairs failed at Tulcea. She was berthed at the Haydarpasa Container Terminal on 24 January.

Ferry broke off her moorings in gale-force winds and crashed into wall of Kiwi Shop at Nedre Strangade in Alesund, Norway. She was reberthed in original position then shifted to Vegsund Slip in Veibust-Naeringomaraade.
BARON suffered mechanical failure, sheltered and dropped anchor at Bozburun anchorage, Turkey. Repair works were carried out by the crew.

Heavy load carrier had mechanical issues at Novorossiysk, Russia. Departure permission was cancelled until repairs and final inspection. As of 30 November vessel was en route from Novorossiysk, Russia, to Tripoli, Lebanon.
A minor damage to hull was discovered during passage to Belfast, UK. The ferry will be drydocked for repairs. An investigation was underway.

The insulation material around exhaust pipes in engine room caught fire near Buiten de Waterpoort in Gorinchem, Netherlands. The fire brigade attended and extinguished fire. Vessel sailed on the next day.
Ferry allided with  ferry quay at Lavik, Norway. She suffered damages above waterline. Sailings between Lavik and Opedal wetre cancelled until further notice.

Vessel suffered water ingress in fore section, while en route from Vung Tau, Vietnam to Cagayan de Oro, Mindanao Island, Philippines. She turned towards Calandorang Bay, eastern coast of Balabac Island where it looks that she was grounded in order to avoid capsizing or even sinking. No reports of leaks or injuries.

Container ship Kuo Lin drifted about 7 miles from the port of Shimizu and struck general cargo vessel Otagawa with the stern. No injuries were reported. Both vessels berthed at Shimizu a few hours later. As of 26 November, Otagawa was en route from Nagoya to Tokuyamakudamatsu, Japan.

UPDATE: 4-Jan-2024 - The Australian Maritime Safety Agency imposed a 180 days ban on the vessel following the incident. Vessel was towed to China and is supposed to arrive on 12 January. UPDATE: Cargo loading operations and production of LNG resumed on 4 December. Reportedly, vessel suffered generator fault and was stuck at the Curtis Island terminal, near Gladstone, Australia, blocking all terminal loading operations. She was towed to outer anchorage on 1 December.

Container ship Kuo Lin drifted about 7 miles from the port of Shimizu and struck general cargo vessel Otagawa with the stern. No injuries were reported. Both vessels berthed at Shimizu a few hours later. Kuo Lin remained moored at Shimizu as of 26 November.

Ro-Ro cargo ship struck a rock, while en route from Hakata to Iwakuni. Vessel was breached and suffered water ingress, with heavy starboard list. All crew were taken of the ship. Tug HAYASE MARU towed her to Yashiro Island. No reports of polution.
Ferry experienced a mechanical fault and had to cancel sailings between Langevag and Buavag, Norway. She was sidelined in Buavag, where the operator will carry out the necessary repairs.
Bulk carrier suffered small ingress of water due to a crack found in one of its port ballast tanks at Rouge River, MI, USA. She sailed on 22 November after repairs.

Reports vessel had navigation, communication and alarm systems failure at Tuapse, Russia, Black Sea. Crew carried out repairs and she was granted permission to depart on 22 November, bound for Samsun.
Fishing vessel experienced greabox issues eight miles southeast of Berry Head, UK. As of 22 November she was near Brighton, in the English Channel and her status was restricted manoeuvrability.

OMSKIY-103 colided with another vessel on Volga in Astrakhan region, near village of Kamenny Yar, Russi. She suffered sctraches and dents above waterline, no holes. No reports of injuries or pollution. Both vessels continued their voyages.
LPG tanker experienced engine failure off Marmara Eregli, Turkey. She was towed to Ambarli anchorage for repairs. She sailed on 22 November.
Ferry's service between Largs and Cumbraes, UK was suspended due to a generator issue that nneeded further investigation. Sailings resumed next day.

Bulk carrier dragged anchor in Chatham Sound, 2.6nm NNW of Table Point, British Columbia. She heaved anchor and awaited for a pilot away from the shoreline. As of 22 November she was en route to Tokuyamakudamatsu, Japan.
Bulk carrier dragged anchor in Chatham Sound, 3.3nm NNW of Table Point, British Columbia. She heaved anchor and awaited for a pilot away from the shoreline.
Vessel's crane tipped over creating a hole in dock of vessel and started taking on water in Tomrefjord, Norway. Vessel listed in starboard and eventually overturned. No injuries were reported.
Service between Sconser and Raasay was briefly suspended due to a generator issue, which was fixed the same day.
Bulk carrier suffered propeller failure during berthing at Saint John, NB, Canada. She was secured and divers attended. Sailed on 26 November.
Passenger ship experienced some technical issues that had to fixed. Day trip from Sandnessjoen was cancelled. Sailings resumed on 24 November.

DENIA was at Yalova ship repair yard, Turkey, when she was caught in strong winds which led to her breaking off moorings. Her hull was breached and suffered water ingress and listed. Was taken under control and capsizing was avoided.

Passenger ship allided with pier after breaking off moorings in strong winds at the inner port of Amasra on the Turkish Black Sea coast. She was secured and reberthed. Structural damage was noted on the side plating, as well as on the aft mooring station. No reports of injuries or pollution.
Vessel was caught in the violent storm in Eregli, Turkey, broke off moorings and allided with pier. She suffered some unconfirmed damages.

Reports vessel was caught in a storm, dragged anchor off Osmangazi Bridge in storm collided with another vessel at Diliskilesi, Turkey. Both vessels sustained damages. NATALI suffered structural damages above the waterline. Repairs were carried out and she was shifted to Yalova anchorage on 7 January. She will carry out sea trials and will be issued new trading certificates.
Vessel was caught in strong winds while at Gemlik, Turkey, Marmara Sea. Her cargo shifted during the storm causing her to list, but she was later stabilised.
MILA was at Eregli, during the violent storm, she broke off moorings and suffered minor damages.
PALLADA was caught in very strong winds at Eregli anchorage, Turkish Black sea coast east of Istanbul. Her anchor dragged, drifted ashore and then broke in two. All crew were rescued safely.
FALCONA and general cargo ship ENKO HASLAMAN collided at Eregli port, during a strong storm. They both drifted into each other causing unknown damages. They remained anchored in inner harbor.

UPDATE: 01-Dec-2023 Fie more bodies were recovered from the wreck. UPDATE: 30-Nov-2023 Turkish authorities have confirmed to have recovered 4 bodies from the bottom of the sea, with 7 still missing. They have declared the entire area a disaster zone. UPDATE: 27-Nov-2023 Search and rescue teams continued searching for 11 crew members missing after the vessel sank to a depth of 25 metres. They have been scanning large areas of the water surface. Underwater robots and drones, safety divers and volunteer divers were also involved in the search. Vessel drifted onto breakwater at Eregli entrance, while en route from Temryuk Russia to Aliaga. She was caught in a storm and called at Eregli for shelter. All people on board were rescued but the vessel was declared missing by officials, probably having sunk after she contacted breakwater.

Vessel collided with product tanker VF Tanker 11 after breaking off moorings at Yalova, Turkey, during strong winds. She suffered damage on the forward section above the water line and was re-berthed at the repair pier.

General cargo ship FALCONA and general cargo ship ENKO HASLAMAN collided at Eregli port, during a strong storm. They both drifted into each other causing unknown damages. They remained anchored in inner harbor.
Ferry was caught in scale 10 Beaufort winds and struggled to berth at Aegina for more than an hour. Vessel had a broken window, but no injuries or water ingress were reported.
Reports vessel was NUC and adrift due to engine fault in southwest lane near Eastbourne, UK. She only stopped for 5 minutes and then continued voyage.

UPDATE: As fo 10 January, the vessel was still at Yalova, where repairs on damaged and deformed locations have begun. Maintenance works are being carried out on the main shaft, propeller, rudder system, and relevant connections. Tanker was struck by an unidentified cargo ship at Yalova ship repair yard, Turkey during the storm that hit the Trukish coast. She sustained some damages.

Bulk carrier suffered another engine failure whie leaving Sept-Ile, 11.30 NM SE of Pointe a la Chasse, QC, Canada. The ship sailed to an anchorage in Baie des Sept-Iles for repairs and sailed on 23 November.
Bulk carrier allided with pier after breaking off moorings at Darica port, Gebze, Turkey. Both vessel and pier sustained damages.
RCC Honolulu received a distress signal from the vessel in the South Pacific Ocean which proved to be a false alert and was cancelled on 20 November.
Vessel experienced engine failure in Brown Passage, 1.60 NM NW Triple Islands, BC, Canada. She proceeded to Prince Rupert for repairs.

Tanker suffered water ingress via propeller shaft, 81 nm NW of Badoc island, northwest Luzon. Crew abandoned ship and were picked up by cargo ship SHENG AN and then transferred to Subic. KING RICH drifted some 620 nm in WSW direction and was found on the coast of Cu Lao Cham island, south of Da Nang, Vietnam, on 1 December.
Ferry suffered propulsion unit failure at Southampton, UK and needed to be towed. Sailing between E Cowess, Isle of Wight and Southampton were cancelled until further notice.

Vessel allided with wharf in Kuviga in Barbu, outside centre of Arendal, Norway after veering off course due to steering issues. The wharf suffered severe damages. The ship proceeded to Eydehavn for repairs and sailed on 21 November.

Vessel suffered engine failure as she was leaving new N.lock of Kiel Canal, Brunsbuttel, Germany. Tugs Fairplay-54 and Luchs towed her out of lock, then tugs Wulf 9 and Wulf 7 towed her to Amsterdam, for permanent repairs.
VENTURA experienced engine fault en route from Hull to Southampton, UK. She was towed to Grimsby Royal Dock by tug Svitzer Castle.

A fire broke out in the engine room, in Gulf of Mexico, en route from Houston, Texas to Altamira, Mexico. Vessels in the vicinity were asked to assist if possible nad report to the RCC New Orleans. The fire was extinguished by the next morning.

Vessel allided with scaffolding protruding into lock chamber upon entering New South Lock of Kiel Canal in Brunsbuttel, Germany. She suffered a four metres port side stern paint abrasion. Sailed one hour later.

A fire broke out in enclosed maintenance hall on Purkholmen at Moen Shipyard in Naeroysund, Norway. Toxic gases were released and fire flared up but taken under control. On 23 November fire erupted once again but was extinguished.
Vessel suffered auxiliary engine failure together with pertinent systems at Tuapse, Russia. She sailed after repairs on 18 November.
Vessel had technical failure at Kumkale point in the Canakkale Strait, en route from Izmir to Gebze, Turkey. She was towed and dropped anchor at Karanlik liman anchorage. Crew carried out repairs.

Bulk carrier sustained damages by mine explosion after departure from Pivdennyi Seaport at Yuzhnyi, Ukraine. There were no reports of injuries. Vessel sailed under own power and will undergo inspections at Romanian port.

Panama Maritime Authority received a request for the emergency docking of the bulk carrier at Puerto Punta Rincón Coal Terminal, among fears the high coal temperature in cargo hold will lead to spontaneous combustion or even an explosion. No tugs or SAR vessels nearby.

Vessel experienced mechanical failure while en route from Samsun, Turkey to Alexandria, Egypt. She sheltered and dropped anchor at Bodrum anchorage. Repairs were done by crew and sailed from anchorage on 19 November.
Cargo ship allided with wharf while leaving section 15 in Sorel, Quebec, Canada assisted by a tug. She continued voyage and as of 20 November she was en route to Casablanca, Morocco.
Vessel spilled more than 100,000 gallons of oil, about 150 km off the coast of Nigeria in Gulf of Guinea. Authorities reacted promptly and most of the sheed on the water surfaces was reduced.

Vessel collided with the bow of ferry WATT SPRINTER and ferry HORIZONT, during turning manoeuvre, having been caught in stormy wind gusts at Harlesiel, Germany. She suffered minor damages and sailed from port on 15 November.

Bulk carrier suffered main engine's lube oil system failure, about 2.70 NM SSE of Colchester Ree, on Lake Erie, Ontario, Canada. She started drifting but crew carried out repairs and resumed voyage same day.

A fire broke out on board after an explosion occured in the engine room, killing one crew member and critically injuring another. The fire was extinguished by the crew, extent of damages not reported as of yet. An inspection will be carried out.

Ferry was struck by ferry Harlingerland which was caught by stormy wind gusts and pushed against quay during turning manoeuvre in port of Harlesiel, Wittmund municipality, Germany, 14 Nov 2023. HORIZONT sailed from port on 16 November.

UPDATE: Vessel was refloated on 13 January and towed to Dung Quat Shipyard in Quang Ngai for repairs. Vessel ran aground on the beach near Central Province of Quang Ngai, while en route from the Cua Lo port in the Central Province of Nghe An to Dung Quat port. There have been several attempts to refloat the ship and as of 10 January, the salvage company carried out sand dredging in order to open a water channel large enough to tow the ship back to sea.

An incident was reported via radio from on board, just past the German Baltic Sea island of Fehmarn, Schleswig Holstein. Patrol ship Neustadt followed closely and a team boarded the ferry at the Kiel-Baltic channel entrance. Additional emergency services, including 3 helicopters arrived the at the scene. The exact nature of this incided is will be announced by the Federal Police in due course.
Vessel had low pressure in main engine and blackout due to stuck up filter in auxiliary engine, nearby Le Conquet, France. Crew carried out repairs and arrived in Brest the same day.
Vessel was suspended due to a technical issue mid Solent, United Kingdom. She departed Southsea as normal, but it appears she was travelling at just 4 knots as she limped back to Ryde.
Vessel suffered mechanical failure at Canakkale Strait, while en route from Dumyat (Damietta), Egypt to Yalova, Turkey. She anchored at Karanlik liman anchorage for repairs.
Ferry had a leak in the fuel line and was sidelined in Saint-Joseph-de-la-Rive Port for repairs. The schedule for Isle-aux-Coudres-Saint-Joseph-de-la-Rive route had to be changed.
Ferry was removed from the service Ardmhor-Eriskay, due to a failure in the propulsion unit. The vessel was moved from Eriskay, to the dock for repair works at Tobermory.

Tanker was boarded by 10 perpetrators armed with long knives, an axe, and steel rods at the Kandla anchorage, Gujarat, western India. They managed to steal 31 valves before the vessel’s horn was sounded, and fled the vessel.

Four stowaways were found in the rudder compartment and apprehended by a Nigerian Navy Ship patrol team, at Lagos Anchorage. They were trying to leave the country on board of the vessel which was en route to Dubai.
Turkish Coast Guard, custom and police narcotic department boarded the vessel off Iskenderun, Turkey and found 52 kgs of cocaine on forecastle deck in way of anchor chain connections.
Vessel experienced mechanical failure after completion of strait passage, wn route from Azov, Russia to Tekirdag, Turkey. She dropped anchor at Yenikapi anchorage and crew started doing repairs.
Bulk carrier suffered main engine failure, about 21.00 NM NE of Cap de la Madeleine, off Grande Vallee, Quebec, Canada She stopped and repairs were carried out while adrift before resuming voyage.

A spill of about 8km/sq was spotted by a Swedish Coast Guard surveillance aircraft and after an analysis of a sample it was confirmed it came from the vessel which cleaned her tanks southwest of Falsterbo. The Master received a fine of $3,580.

Vessel contaminated the waters of Puerto de La Luz, Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, during fuel transfer operations. An operation was launched to monitor, control and clean up the spill, while de vessel was detained and sanctioned. She sailed on 3 December after paying a guarantee of approximately $400,000.
Ferry had to return to Cagayan de Oro, Philippines after she developed portside list as she left the port. All passengers have been disembarked. No reports on cause of list.

Vessel struck embankment in Kiel Canal after passing Rader Hochbruke Bridge, en route from Netherlands to Gdansk, Poland. Transit was prohibited and she was taken to Rendsburg by two tugs. No reports on damages or cause of accident.
Vessel allided a wharf on arrival in Sorel, Quebec, Canada. She was secured and the crew conducted a damage assessment.
Tanker was NUC due to loss of steering in English Channel, UK. No pollution. She anchored in pos 50 35 47N, 002 24 50W to carry out repairs and sailed on 14 November.
Reports vessel suffered mechanical failure in the North Sea about 60nm east of Grimsby, UK and was NUC. Tug assistance has been requested
Vessel suffered mechanical failure and moored at Dikili anchorage, Turkey. Repairs were carried out by the crew
Vessel had technical failure at Novorossiysk, Russia. Departure permission was granted on 13 November, after repairs were carried out and state surveyor certificate was povided.

Ferry collided with pier II, at Heraklionm Greece, during berthing and mooring operations. No reports of injuries or pollution. She continued scheduled service after a sea worthiness cartificate was presented.
Tanker allided with staircase while docking at central wall of new northern lock of Kiel Canal in Brunsbuttel, Germany. She continued voyage the same day, after a inside lock chamber inspection.

A fire erupted on board the vessel due to overheating of some of system's batteries that provide energy, at Fusina, Italy, Pier 2. No injuries reported.. Port Authority, together with Fire Brigade intervened, limiting damages.

A crew member was medevaced by the Indian Coast Guard with critical injuries after he fell 20ft into an empty cargo hold, at Port Blair South Andaman Island. He was transferred to Port Blair with multiple fractures.
Vessel suffered mechanical failure at Canakkale Strait, Turkey. She shifted and dropped anchor at Karanlik Liman anchorage. Repairs were being carried out by crew.

A fire erupted on board the landing craft 3NM from Lembeh Island, en route from Bitung to Almahera, Indonesia. 14 people on board were safely rescued by VOYAGER 03. The fire was extinguished the same day.

Ferry had a steering system fault and reported to have allided with unidentified object, in Bari, Italy. She suffered damages to the bow and was not able to depart for Durres. She sailed same day after reapirs.
Tanker ran aground approximately 2 cables off southwest Sakhalin coast near Lopatino Cape, Japan sea. Vessel has about 700 tons of fuel on board, no leaks reported. A tug was deployed to assist.

An unknown number of passengers were infected with Covid-19 during an 18-day round trip from Adelaide to Queensland. The cruise ship docked in Melbourne and passengers needing urgent medical care were transferred to hospital.

A fire erupted on board the vessel during repair works, when sparks fell on a pipe causing fire and reportedly an explosion. One of the workers died and other three were taken to Government Kilpauk Medical College Hospital. An investigation was launched.
Vessel suffered mechanical failure in Canakkale Strait, Turkey, en route from Marmara Ereglisi, Turkey. She anchored at Karanlik liman anchorage and sailed the next day after repairs.

Vessel was hit by a Russian missile while it was docked at the Ukrainian port of Pivdennyi. An Engine Trainee suffered a fracture, while the ship’s captain and Third Mate sustained minor injuries. Of the 25 crew members, 17 have returned home.

Bulk carrier ran aground while entering Natal port, Brazil, above Newton Navarro Bridge, as she arrived from Kavkaz port, Russia. She was refloated in under 3 hours with tug assistance and then escorted to berth. No reports on damages or leaks.

Vessel experienced loss of propulsion due to engine failure in the Canal de la Rive-Sud, Quebec. She had to drop anchor in order to avoid grounding. Temporary repairs were carried out and the ship moved to a wharf at Cote Sainte-Catherine, Quebec for further assessment.

Vessel ran aground just outside Saltholmen, Sweden. She suffered two leaks, hull was breached with water ingress. Swedish Coast Guard deployed 3 boats to refloat. VIPAN docked at Ockero Boatyard AB. Cause of grounding not reported.
Ferry had steering issues in Ardrossan, UK. LOCH FYNE replaced her on shuttles between Claonaig and Lochranza. Repairs were carried out and resumed service on 12 November.
Vessel was reported NUC as she was unable to put engines in astern, 4.2NM from Dover, UK. She sailed after repairs were completed.

A fire erupted in engine room as vessel entered the Lock in Brunsbuettel, Kiel Canal, while en route from Spain to Sweden. She was moored in Lock where a big number of fire engines have attended and will be towed after fire is extinguished. Traffic was affected with ships lining up off Brunsbuettel, in Elbe and up the Canal.

A crew member was medevaced by the US Coast Guard, 9nm south of Dauphin Island, Alabama. The man experienced breathing difficulties and high blood pressure. He was airlifted and transferred to Mobile International Airport, from where an ambulance took him to hospital.
Cement carreir allided with wharf while secured in Bowmanville, Ontario, Canada. She suffered hull damages and proceeded to Hamilton, Ontario, for repairs. She sailed from Hamilton on 25 November.
Vessel experienced seawater valve failure, in Le Grand Chenal off Montreal, Canada. Engine room was flooded. Vessel was secured alongside section No. 98 for repairs.

Ferry was hit by general cargo ship NEW RAOUF, in Black Sea, 80 nm east of Varna, Bulgaria. NEW RAOUF was supposed to give way to SLAVYANIN. The ferry had hull breaches and 3 tanks were flooded and had to return to Varna. Meanwhile the cargo ship fled the scene and sailed at high speed towards Turkey Straits, but authorities had been alerted already.

NEW RAOUF failed to give way and struck Russian cargo ferry SLAVYANIN, in Black sea, 80 nm E of Varna, Bulgaria, while en route to Egypt. She fled the scene and sailed towards Turkey Straits where Turkish authorities were awaiting. Reports that AIS log had been tampered with trying to position the vessel somewhere in Sevastopol Naval Base, Crimea.
Ferry suffered mechanical failure. The North Carolina Department of Transportation Ferry Division announced that operations will be cancelled for the rest of the day.

Vessel suffered mechanical failure while en route from Azov, Russia to Alexandropoulis, Greec. She anchored at Sinop anchorage, Turkey. Crew carried out repairs and vessel resumed voyage on 10 November.
Bulk carrier suffered technical failure of auxiliary engine along with alarm system at Novorossiysk, Russia. She sailed from Novorossiysk on 20 November after repairs were carried out.

Vessel was fined by Turkish customes after they found discrepancies between the arrival fuel declaration and the actual quantity measured after inspection. The fine was paid and vessel sailed on the next day, bound for Port Said.
Ferry hit south end of Glasgow wharf as she was leaving Wellington, New Zealand. She suffered a dent on hull and a very small hole above waterline which presented low risk.

Fishing vessel ran aground in Race Passage, BC, Canada. Another fishing vessel nearby attempted to free her but fouled her propeller. Coast Guard vessel CAPE PALMERSTON refloated her and she headed to Campbell River under own power.
Reports vessel ran aground  in St. Clair river in front of Marine City, while en route from Detroit to East Marina, USA. US Coast Guard assisting.

Fishing vessel was disabled due to fouled propeller while assisting grounded fishing vessel STAR WARS II in Race Passage, BC, Canada. She was anchored to avoid grounding until towed to Kelsey Bay by Coast Guard vessel.
Ferry experienced port side main engine failure and remained stationary at the Telford Dock in Aberdeen. She was replaced by ferry FINLAGGAN on the route Oban-Colonsay.

Ferry had issues with the aft ramp and required repairs by contractors. She was removed from the Tayinloan-Gigha service and was expected to resume on the 9 November after repair works were carried out.

Ferry was temporarily sidelined from Colintrave-Rhubodach service due to issues with aft main engine. Repairs were carried out and resumed sailing the next day but issue reoccured and was sideline again as engineer attendance was required.
Tanker had to shutdown main engine, about 2.40 NM SW of Ilets Frechette, in the St. Lawrence River off Neuville, Quebec, Canada. Crew carried out repairs and resumed sailing.

Bulk carrier was NUC in English Channel, heading west. Crew had to change filters on the main engines and as of 8 November vessel was in the Bay of Biscay, en route from Rotterdam, Netherlands to Paranagua, Brazil.
Container ship was NUC due to bearing alarm fault in engine room in the English Channel, UK. The cause was a faulty sensor and there were no issues with engine. She continued voyage after repairs.

Cocaine with street value of $50.00 million was found on board vessel as she arrived in Hong Kong. Apparently, two men boarded the vessel while docked in Guatemala and smuggled drugs to be delivered in Hong Kong.
Ferry experienced engine failure off Amasra, Turkey and drifted with wind and current while crew and shore based tech support carried out repairs. Vessel resumed voyage on 8 November.
While berthed at Eastern Jetty, fully cellular containership APL Houston struck the vessel due to engine problem while entering Cape Town's Duncan Dock, South Africa. Damages unknown.

Bulk carrier allided with a protruding metal plate from a dock while departing Port de Gros-Cacouna, Quebec. She suffered hull damages and headed to an anchorage off Les Razades for repairs. No reports of leaks.
Bulk carrier had technical failure at Canakkale strait, Turkey and shifted to Karanlik liman anchorage for repairs.

APL HOUSTON collided with portside bow of berthed cable ship NIWA due to engine problems while entering Cape Town's Duncan Dock, South Africa. She sailed from Cape Town on 9 November. No reports on damages.

Cruise ship experienced engine difficulties, which impacted maximum cruising speed. Two ports of call were cancelled. Vessel was taken out of service after 11 November and taken to dry dock for repairs.
Bulk carreir ran aground in Detroit River off Amherstburg, ON, 0.87NM North of Bois Blanc Island, Canada. She headed to an anchorage off Ojibway and sailed from there on 07 November.

Tanker was detained by the Malaysian Maritime Department after transferring diesel onto oil products tanker SCORPIO. Two crew members from each vessel were also detained for further investigation as they failed to provide oil transfer permits.

Tanker was detained by the Malaysian Maritime Department after transferring diesel from oil products tanker Tuah Sejagat. Two crew members from each vessel were also detained for further investigation as they failed to provide oil transfer permits.
Tanker experienced mechanical fault and had to moor at Datca anchorage, Turkey. Repairs were carried out by the crew.
Reports vessel had debris in propeller, while secured in Grande-Anse, Quebec, Canada. Divers freed the propeller and she sailed on the next day.
Vessel's service between Gourock and Dunoon had to be suspended to allow further investigations, after a technical issue.
Container ship was NUC due to engine failure in North Sea waters, UK. She resumed voyage the same day and arrived in the Port of El Dekheila, Egypt on 18 November.
Search and rescue vessel had breakdown while transferring canoes accumulated in La Restinga to Tenerife. She left 3 towed boats adrift and returned to La Estaca for repairs.
Perpetrators boarded vessel at Vung Tau anchorage, Vietnam. Alarm was raised, crew mustered and search conducted. The incident was reported to Vung Tau port authorities.

Container ship suffered leakage of main engine exhaust valve and was NUC 18 NM South Berry Head, UK. Repairs were carried out and vessel resumed voyage the same day. She arrived in Tangier 8 November.
Vessel had a total failure of its bow thruster's generator, about 2.10 NM N of Ile du Grenadier, on Lac Saint-Fran?ois, Canada. She anchored off Saint-Zotique and crew carried out repairs.
Vessel ran aground onto small islet off Larymna port, Phthiotis, North Euboean Gulf, Greece, Aegean sea, en route from Istanbul. No reports on leaks or damages.
Vessel (experienced mechanical failure and sheltered and dropped anchor in Sinop anchorage, Turkey. Repairs were carried out by crew.
Cruise ship had her propeller entangled in mooring lines, as she was about to leave Piraeus, Greece, bound for Palermo, Italy. Departure was postponed until next day.
A crew member was medevaced by US Coast Guard helicopter, 250nm northeast of Nassau, Bahamas, after suffering with severe stomach pain. He was handed over to emergency medical services in Nassau.

A crew member was in need of immediate hospital treatment  while moored at the anchorage of the port of Nafplio, Greece. The man was taken to the General Hospital of Argos Argolida for further medical examinations.
Bulk carrier experienced main engine failure while on departure from Trois-Rivieres, Canada. Crew assessed issue on the spot and sailed from Trois-Rivieres on 5 November after repairs.
Bulk carrier suffered exhaust system failure, about 1.80 NM SSW of Pointe a Page, in the St. Lawrence River off Donnacona. Repairs were carried out by crew.

A fire broke out after an explosion in void tank at bottom of pump room, while shipyard workers were welding hull, at Dung Quat Shipyard in Quang Ngai Province, Vietnam. 9 people suffered burns in CO2 cylinder explosion.

A fire broke out on deck no 7 while en route from Balikpapan to Pantoloan port, Indonesia. Vessel suffered some damages but no injuries were reported. Vessel was berthed at Pantoloan, for repaira and sailed the same day, bound for Bitung port.
Tanker had mechanical fault due to issues with injectors in main engine and drifted from NE lane to SW lane in Dover Straits. Repairs were carried out and vessel continued passage the next day.
Eight Nigerian stowaways were found inside the vessel's rudder compartment. They were apprehended by Nigerian Navy ship NNS Beecroft.
Vessel was NUC due to main engine issue with the fuel pump, about 33 NM from Southwold. An engineer on board rectified the issue.
Tanker suffred cooling system failure, about 32.40 Nm NW of Rochers aux Oiseaux, Canada. The crew assessed the issue and resumed the voyage.
Bulk carrier ran aground at 104.2 kilometer mark in Martin Garcia channel, Rio de la Plata,  while sailing to Villa Constitucion port, Argentina. Reports say she grounded on Channel's edge.

Cruise ship was caught in storm Ciaran and had flooded cabins, broken windows and injured passengers. She has to take refuge in Getxo, Spain. Deck four suffered some damages as well. She sailed from Getxo on 5 November.

Cargo ship experienced mechanical failure at Canakkale strait near Kepez point, Turkey. She shifted and anchored at Karanlik liman anchorage. Sailing was prohibited until repairs and sea worthiness certificate issued.
Cargo ship experienced main engine failure due to a fault in the fuel supply system, in Halifax Harbour, Canada. Vessel dropped anchor and crew carried out repairs. She sailed on 4 November.
Bulk carrier had starboard windlass failure, while heaving up anchor about 2.10 NM SSE of Point Atkinson, in English Bay, Canada. Crew carried out repairs.
Vessel suffered port windlass failure while heaving up anchor, about 2.60 NM SSE of Point Atkinson, in English Bay, British Columbia, Canada. Crew assessed the issue.

Vessel suffered water ingress due to technical error and developed sheavy list to port side at port of Ockero, Sweden. Water was pumped and vessel was straightened. The cause of the incident was water ballast flowing from one side to another.

Hospital ship, which provides aid in Lautoka, Fiji, suffered mechanical issues related to the tail shaft. YWAM Ships is appealing for help with the cost of repairs. They pais an initial $100k but need another $200k before the end of the month.
Cargo ship experienced mechanical failure and sheltered at Cesme anchorage, Turkey. Crew carried out repairs by crew and she sailed on 5 November.
Fishing vessel suffered engine failure and berthed about 4 NM from Stockholm. ALB towed her to Dale anchorage and handed over to tug Forth Trojan.
Danish maritime authorities reported that vessel ran aground off Logstor, in Limfjord, Denmark. Channel was closed due to silting and mariners were advised to keep well clear.
Vessel had engine failure at Tekirdag, Turkey . Crew couldn't carry out repairs and tug Ayaz Bey towed her to Tuzla shipyard. Damage survey was in progress.

Six French military tanks have falled overboard 60km west of the Hague, in extreme weather conditions. A massive search force including a French Navy helicopter and an aircraft were deployed. One of the tanks was soon located and crew tried to tow it towards Cherbourg, but the tow line broke in high winds. The tank was again located near Raz Blanchard and four clearance divers hoisted it on the rear deck of the vessel.

Vessel discharged soot from Exhaust Gas Control Systems into water, after power outage, while preparing to depart pier in Grand Turk,Turks and Caicos Islands.Her departure was delayed. Investigation underway.

General cargo ship had mechanical fault in the Northern entrance of the Istanbul Strait, en route from Trabzon to Tuzla, Turkey. Vessel continued transit with tug assistance and sailed to Desan Yardgem United Shipyards for permanent repairs.

Cargo ship experienced engine failure at W of Istanbul anchorage, off Bakirkoy, Turkey. Tug Kurtarma 12 and technical team attended as vessel was drifting with wind. She was later anchored at Ahirkapi.
Ferry was removed from route Stokkvag-Onoy-Lovund-Sleneset, Norway due to mechanical failure. She was sent to Sandnessjoen for repairs and ferry Lovund replaced her.
A leak was discovered on starboard side of vessel and had to be removed from route Barra - Uist, UK. Repairs were carried out and she resumed service the next day.

Reports of vessel taking on water east of Bjornoya, Norway, between Norwegian Sea and Barents Sea. Two bilge pumps were brought on board by helicopter to pump water out from engine room. Vessel docked later in Breivika.

General cargo ship was caught in rough weather en route to Marina di Carrara, west of La Spezia, Italy. She suffered water ingress in engine room, but was taken under control. The vessel was allowed to shelter at La Spezia due to deteriorating weather.
Vessel suffered failure of communication unit together with emergency public address system at Novorossiysk, Russia. Repairs were carried out and she was granted permission to sail on 3 November.

Bulk carrier experineced mechanical failure due to a fault in the electrical supply system, in the St. Lawrence River off L'Isle-aux-Coudres, Canada. She arrived in Baie Comeau, Canada and sailed on 5 November after repairs.

Ferry was out of service since 30 October until 7 November due to a technical issue. She sailed from Rosslare to Fishguard at reduced speed, then sailed from Fishguard  on 6 November for around 2 hours of trials.

A crew member's body was recovered from the sea after a multi-agency search. An investigation into the circumstances is ongoing, but no foul play is suspected. The vessel was at Gibraltar since 13 September.
Vessel had a technical issue and had to be sideline until 6 November. She was berthed in Otternish and ferry Loch Bhrusda replaced her.
Vessel's deck crane allided with a bridge in the Portwert area of Duisburg-Ruhrort, while attempting to lift a car from the vessel onto the quay. No reports of injuried or damages.
Vessel experienced engine failure in the St. Lawrence River off Deschambault, Quebec, Canada. She was anchored and crew carried out repairs.
A passenger fell into water while vessel was en route from Barcelona to Florida. The voyage was interrupted and the vessel turned back to conduct a search. He was successfully rescued within an hour.
Ferry had engine trouble on her route between Marstal and Rudkobing. She remained docked at Marstam and was expected to be out of service until 6 November.

Reports vessel had steering failure after leaving Brake, Weser river, bound for Hamburg, and ran aground onto Harriersand island coast. She was refloated and towed back to Brake. She was permitted to sail after inspection and class safety confirmation, on 31 October.

Vessel was seized at the Federal Ocean Terminal in Onne, Eleme Council Area of Rivers State, Nigeria after it's been reported that she was laden with 300,000 litres of illegally refined diesel, stored in large black plastic tanks. Two crew members were arrested.
Ferry sailing between Endelave and Snaptun, Denmark, had technical problems and had to sail to shipyard after last scheduled trip. She will be docked at the shipyard until 5 November.

Reports that approximatley 400 migrants blocked the ferry ramp, which led to conflict between them and the passengers of the ferry. The migrants were demanding they be transferred out of Rhodes. Vessel's service between Aegeon and Pelagos resumed shortly.

Deck cargo ship ran aground on Carabao island coast, Tablas Strai, central Philippines. She suffered dents and scratches to hull, but still seaworthy. No injuries reported. As of 30 October vessel was probably refloated.
Reports tug was disabled with a fouled propeller, while towing barge M6001 in the9157105South Arm of the Fraser River. Vessel was towed to Richmond, by tug Captain Cook.

Cargo ship sufered mechanical failure at Kilitbahir poin, Canakkale Strait, Turkey. A tug assisted and shifted to Karanlik liman anchorage. A fine was imposed and departure permission cancelled until repairs were carried out.
A fire broke out in the accommodation area, in Belaya Rive, Russia. 3 cabins burned. No reports of casualties or pollution.
Crankshaft of the main engine broke and vessel had to drop anchor off the coast of Falkenberg. She was towed to Halmstad for repairs.
Ferry had engine failure due to a broken rod. Service between Kingston and Edmonds was reduced as vessel had to be sidelined due to signigicant damage. As of 1 November she was docked at Bermerton.
